sections.ger: Die Welt ist alles was der Fall ist.
sections.pmc: The world is all that is the case.
sections.str: The world is all that is the case.

sections.ger: Was der Fall ist, die Tatsache, ist das Bestehen von Sachverhalten.
sections.pmc: What is the case - a fact - is the existence of states of affairs.
sections.str: What is the case—a fact—is the obtaining of elementary facts.

sections.ger: Das logische Bild der Tatsachen ist der Gedanke.
sections.pmc: A logical picture of facts is a thought.
sections.str: A thought is a logical picture of facts.

sections.ger: Der Gedanke ist der sinnvolle Satz.
sections.pmc: A thought is a proposition with a sense.
sections.str: A thought is a sentence with a sense.

sections.ger: Der Satz ist eine Wahrheitsfunktion der Elementarsätze.
sections.pmc: A proposition is a truth-function of elementary propositions.
sections.str: A proposition is a truth-function of elementary propositions.

sections.ger:
Die allgemeine Form der Wahrheitsfunktion ist:
|N(p̅0), ᾱ, N(ᾱ)|
sections.pmc:
The general form of a truth-function is
|N(p̅0), ᾱ, N(ᾱ)|
sections.str: The general form of a truth-function is: |N(p̄0), ᾱ, N(ᾱ)|.pt

sections.ger: Wovon man nicht sprechen kann, darüber muß man schweigen.
sections.pmc: What we cannot speak about we must pass over in silence.
sections.str: Of what we cannot speak we must be silent.

sections.ger: Die Welt ist die Gesamtheit der Tatsachen, nicht der Dinge.
sections.pmc: The world is the totality of facts, not of things.
sections.str: The world is all that is the case.

sections.ger: Die Welt ist durch die Tatsachen bestimmt und dadurch, daß es alle Tatsachen sind.
sections.pmc: The world is determined by the facts, and by their being all the facts.
sections.str: The world is determined by the facts, and by these being all the facts.

sections.ger: Denn die Gesamtheit der Tatsachen bestimmt was der Fall ist und auch was alles nicht der Fall ist.
sections.pmc: For the totality of facts determines what is the case, and also whatever is not the case.
sections.str: For the totality of facts determines what is the case, and also whatever is not the case.

sections.ger: Die Tatsachen im logischen Raum sind die Welt.
sections.pmc: The facts in logical space are the world.
sections.str: The facts in logical space are the world.

sections.ger: Der Sachverhalt ist eine Verbindung von Gegenständen, Sachen.
sections.pmc: A state of affairs (a state of things) is a combination of objects (things).
sections.str: An elementary fact is a combination of objects (entities, things).

sections.ger: Der Gegenstand ist einfach.
sections.pmc: Objects are simple.
sections.str: An object is simple.

sections.ger: Im Sachverhalt hängen die Gegenstände ineinander wie die Glieder einer Kette.
sections.pmc: In a state of affairs objects fit into one another like the links of a chain.
sections.str: In an elementary fact objects are interconnected, like the links of a chain.

sections.ger: Die Gesamtheit der bestehenden Sachverhalte ist die Welt.
sections.pmc: The totality of existing states of affairs is the world.
sections.str: Die Gesamtheit der bestehenden Sachverhalte ist die Welt.

sections.ger: Die Gesamtheit der bestehenden Sachverhalte bestimmt auch, welche Sachverhalte nicht bestehen.
sections.pmc: The totality of existing states of affairs also determines which states of affairs do not exist.
sections.str: The totality of obtaining elementary facts also determines which elementary facts do not obtain.

sections.ger: Das Bestehen und nicht Bestehen von Sachverhalten ist die Wirklichkeit.
sections.pmc: The existence and non-existence of states of affairs is reality.
sections.str: The obtaining or non-obtaining of elementary facts is reality.

sections.ger: Die gesamte Wirklichkeit ist die Welt.
sections.pmc: The sum-total of reality is the world.
sections.str: The sum total of reality is the world.

sections.ger: 〟Ein Sachverhalt ist denkbar" (〟vorstellbar") heißt: Wir können uns ein Bild von ihm machen.
sections.pmc: 'A state of affairs is thinkable (imaginable)'; what this means is that we can picture it to ourselves.
sections.str: “A elementary proposition is thinkable (imaginable)” means: we can imagine it.

sections.ger: Die Gesamtheit der Sätze ist die Sprache.
sections.pmc: The totality of propositions is the language.
sections.str: The totality of propositions is language.

sections.ger: Jeder Satz läßt sich auffassen als Resultat einer Operation, welche mit einem anderen Satz (der Basis der Operation) vorgenommen wurde und diesen in jenen verwandelt.
sections.pmc: Every proposition can be construed as the result of an operation which is performed on another proposition (which is the base of the operation) and which turns the latter into the former.
sections.str: Every proposition can be construed as the result of an operation which is performed on another proposition (the operation’s base) and turns the latter into the former.

sections.ger: Das Vorkommen einer Operation im Satz kann natürlich allein nichts besagen.
sections.pmc: Of course the mere occurrence of an operation in a proposition cannot say anything.
sections.str: Of course the mere occurrence of an operation in a proposition cannot say anything.

sections.ger: Jeden Klammerausdruck dessen Glieder Sätze sind schreiben wir in der Form 〟(α)". 〟α" ist eine Variable, deren Werte die Glieder des Klammerausdruckes sind. Der Strich über dem 〟α" bedeutet, daß alle Werte von α in der Klammer stehen.
sections.pmc: Any bracketed proposition whose terms are propositions we write in form '(ᾱ)'. '(ᾱ)' is a variable whose values are terms of the bracketed expression. The bar over 'α' means that all values of α stand between the brackets.
sections.str: Any bracketed proposition whose terms are propositions we write in form “(ᾱ)”. “(ᾱ)” is a variable whose values are terms of the bracketed expression. The line over “α” means that all values of α stand between the brackets.

sections.ger: Welche Werte α annehmen darf, wird festgesetzt.
sections.pmc: What values α can take is something that is stipulated.
sections.str: The values of α are set by stipulation.

sections.ger: Die Festsetzung der Werte der Satzvariablen ist die Angabe der Sätze, welche die Variable vertritt.
sections.pmc: To stipulate values for a propositional variable is to give the propositions of which the variable is the representative.
sections.str: Values for a sentential variable are stipulated by indicating the sentences which the variable represents.

sections.ger: In der allgemeinen Satzform kommt der Satz im Satz nur als W-Argument vor.
sections.pmc: In the general propositional form propositions occur in other propositions only as T-arguments.
sections.str: In the general propositional form propositions occur in other propositions only as truth arguments.

sections.ger: Nun scheint es aber auf den ersten Blick als könne ein Satz in einem anderen auch auf andere Weise vorkommen.
sections.pmc: But at first sight it looks as if it were also possible for one proposition to occur in another in a different way.
sections.str: But at first sight it looks as if there were another way in which one proposition could occur in another.

sections.ger: Besonders in gewissen psychologischen Satzformen wie 〟A glaubt, daß p" oder 〟A denkt p", etc. Hier scheint es nämlich oberflächlich als stünde der Satz p zu einem Gegenstand A in einer Art Relation — und in der modernen Erkenntnistheorie (Russell, Moore, etc.) sind jene Sätze auch so aufgefaßt worden.
sections.pmc: Particularly with certain forms of proposition in psychology, such as 'A believes that p' or 'A has the thought p', etc. For if these are considered superficially, it looks as if the proposition p stood in some kind of relation to an object A - and in modern theory of knowledge (Russell, Moore, etc.) these propositions have actually been construed in this way.
sections.str: Especially in certain forms of proposition in psychology, such as “A believes that p” or “A thinks p”, etc. On the surface, it looks as if the proposition p stood in some kind of relation to an object A - and in modern theory of knowledge (Russell, Moore, etc.) these propositions have actually been construed in this way.

sections.ger: Es ist aber klar daß 〟A glaubt , daß", 〟A denkt p" 〟A sagt p" von der Form 〟‚p’ sagt p" sind; und hier ist es klar daß es sich nicht um eine Zuordnung von einer Tatsache und einem Gegenstand sondern um die Zuordnung von Tatsachen durch Zuordnung ihrer Gegenstände handelt.
sections.pmc: It is clear, however, that 'A believes that p', 'A has the thought that p', and 'A says p' are of the form '"p" says p'; and it is clear that this does not involve a correlation of a fact with an object but rather the correlation of facts by means of the correlation of their objects.
sections.str: Clearly, however, “A believes that p”, “A thinks p”, and “A says p” are of the form “‘p’ says p”; and clearly this is n0t a matter of a correlation of fact to objec,t but rather the correlation of facts by correlation of their objects.

sections.ger: Einen Komplex wahrnehmen heißt, wahrnehmen, daß sich seine Bestandteile so und so zu einander verhalten.
sections.pmc: To perceive a complex means to perceive that its constituents are related to one another in such and such a way.
sections.str: Perceiving a complex means perceiving the way that its constituents are related to one another.

sections.ger: Die Welt zerfällt in Tatsachen.
sections.pmc: The world divides into facts.
sections.str: What is the case—a fact—is the obtaining of elementary facts.

sections.ger: Eines kann der Fall sein oder nicht der Fall sein und alles übrige gleichbleiben.
sections.pmc: Each item can be the case or not the case while everything else remains the same.
sections.str: Each one can either be the case or not be the case and all else remains the same.

sections.ger: Es ist dem Ding wesentlich der Bestandteil eines Sachverhalts sein zu können.
sections.pmc: It is essential to things that they should be possible constituents of states of affairs.
sections.str: It is essential to a thing that it can be a constituent of an elementary fact.

sections.ger: Jede Aussage über Komplexe läßt sich in eine Aussage über deren Bestandteile und die Sätze zerlegen welche die Komplexe vollständig beschreiben.
sections.pmc: Every statement about complexes can be resolved into a statement about their constituents and into the propositions that describe the complexes completely.
sections.str: Every statement about complexes can be broken down into a statement about their constituents and into the propositions that completely describe the complexes.

sections.ger:
Die Gegenstände bilden die Substanz der Welt. 
Darum können sie nicht zusammengesetzt sein.
sections.pmc:
Objects make up the substance of the world.
That is why they cannot be composite.
sections.str: Objects make up the substance of the world. That is why they cannot be composite.pt

sections.ger: Hätte die Welt keine Substanz so würde, ob ein Satz Sinn hat, davon abhängen, ob ein anderer Satz wahr ist.
sections.pmc: If the world had no substance, then whether a proposition had sense would depend on whether another proposition was true.
sections.str: If the world had no substance, then whether a proposition made sense would depend on whether another proposition was true.

sections.ger: Es wäre dann unmöglich ein Bild der Welt (wahr oder falsch) zu entwerfen.
sections.pmc: In that case we could not sketch out any picture of the world (true or false).
sections.str: In that case we could not form a picture of the world (true or false).

sections.ger: Im Sachverhalt verhalten sich die Gegenstände in bestimmter Art und Weise zu einander.
sections.pmc: In a state of affairs objects stand in a determinate relation to one another.
sections.str: In an elementary fact objects are combined in a definite way.

sections.ger: Das Bestehen von Sachverhalten nennen wir auch eine positive — , das Nichtbestehen eine negative Tatsache.
sections.pmc: We also call the existence of states of affairs a positive fact, and their non-existence a negative fact.
sections.str: We also call the obtaining of elementary facts a positive fact, and their non-obtaining a negative fact.pt?	29[1]	—		AüL 193 (7)**  MN 219 (4)+ We can say that “~Socrates” means nothing because there is no property called ~(x).

sections.ger: Die Sachverhalte sind von einander unabhängig.
sections.pmc: States of affairs are independent of one another.
sections.str: Elementary facts are independent of one another.pt

sections.ger: Die Gesamtheit der wahren Gedanken sind ein Bild der Welt.
sections.pmc: The totality of true thoughts is a picture of the world.
sections.str: The totality of true thoughts is a picture of the world.

sections.ger:
Der Gedanke enthält die Möglichkeit der Sachlage, die er denkt.
Was denkbar ist, ist auch möglich.
sections.pmc:
A thought contains the possibility of the situation of which it is the thought.
What is thinkable is possible too.
sections.str: A thought contains the possibility of the situation of which it is the thought. What is thinkable is possible too.

sections.ger: Wir können nichts Unlogisches denken, weil wir sonst unlogisch denken müßten.
sections.pmc: Thought can never be of anything illogical, since, if it were, we should have to think illogically.
sections.str: We cannot think anything illogical, for otherwise we would have to think illogically.

sections.ger: Ein a priori richtiger Gedanke wäre ein solcher, dessen Möglichkeit seine Wahrheit bedingte.
sections.pmc: If a thought were correct a priori, it would be a thought whose possibility ensured its truth.
sections.str: An a priori correct thought would be one whose possibility ensured its truth.

sections.ger: Nur so könnten wir a priori wissen, daß ein Gedanke wahr ist, wenn aus dem Gedanken selbst (ohne Vergleichsobjekt) seine Wahrheit zu erkennen wäre.
sections.pmc: A priori knowledge that a thought was true would only be possible if its truth were recognizable from the thought itself (without anything to compare it with).
sections.str: One could know a priori that a thought is true only if its truth were recognizable from the thought itself (without any object of comparison).

sections.ger: Der Mensch besitzt die Fähigkeit Sprachen zu bauen womit sich jeder Sinn ausdrücken läßt, ohne eine Ahnung davon zu haben wie, und was jedes Wort bedeutet. Wie man auch spricht ohne zu wissen wie die einzelnen Laute hervorgebracht werden.
sections.pmc: Man possesses the ability to construct languages capable of expressing every sense, without having any idea how each word has meaning or what its meaning is - just as people speak without knowing how the individual sounds are produced.
sections.str: Human beings have the capacity to construct languages in which every sense can be expressed, without having any idea how and what each word means,  just as we speak without knowing how the individual sounds are produced.

sections.ger: Analog kann man von Operationen mit mehreren Basen sprechen. 〟(F)(p)" ist das Resultat der Operation 〟F( )" auf die Basis p, (FWWF)(p,q) das Resultat einer Operation auf zwei Basen.
sections.pmc: Similarly we can speak of an operation with several bases. '(F)(p)' is the result of the operation 'F( )' on the base p; (FTTF)(p, q) is the result of an operation on two bases.
sections.str: Similarly we can speak of an operation with several bases. “(F)(p)” is the result of the operation “F( )” on the base p; (FTTF )(p, q) is the result of an operation on two bases.

sections.ger: Eine Operation sagt ja nicht aus, nur ihr Resultat und dies hängt von ihrer Basis ab.
sections.pmc: Indeed, no statement is made by an operation, but only by its result, and this depends on its base.
sections.str: Indeed, no statement is made by an operation, but only by its result, and this depends on its base.

sections.ger: Die Festsetzung der Werte ist die Variable.
sections.pmc: The stipulation of values is the variable.
sections.str: The stipulation of values is the variable.pt

sections.ger: Die Festsetzung ist eine Beschreibung dieser Sätze.
sections.pmc: The stipulation is a description of those propositions.
sections.str: The description of those sentences is the stipulation.

sections.ger: Die Festsetzung wird also nur von Zeichen nicht von deren Bedeutung handeln.
sections.pmc: The stipulation will therefore be concerned only with signs, not with their meaning.
sections.str: The stipulation will therefore be concerned only with signs, not with their meaning.

sections.ger:
Die allgemeine Form der Operation ist:
|σ̅, α̅, N(α̅)|'(σ̅).
sections.pmc:
The general form of an operation is
|σ̅, α̅, N(α̅)|'(σ̅)
sections.str: The general form of an operation is |σ̅ , α̅, N(α̅ )|'(σ)

sections.ger: Die allgemeine Form der ganzen Zahl ist: |O, α, α + 1|.
sections.pmc: The general form of an integer is |0, α, α+1|.
sections.str: The general form of an integer is |0, α, α +1|.

sections.ger: Dies zeigt auch daß die Seele — das Subjekt etc. — wie sie in der heutigen oberflächlichen Psychologie aufgefaßt wird ein Unding ist.
sections.pmc: This shows too that there is no such thing as the soul - the subject, etc. - as it is conceived in the superficial psychology of the present day.
sections.str: This also shows too that there is no such thing as the soul - the subject, etc. - as it is conceived in contemporary superficial psychology.

sections.ger:
Dies erklärt wohl auch daß man die Figur 

auf zweierlei Art als Würfel sehen kann; und alle ähnlichen Erscheinungen. Denn wir sehen eben wirklich zwei verschiedene Tatsachen. (Sehe ich erst auf die Ecke a und nur flüchtig auf b so erscheint a vorn und umgekehrt.)
sections.pmc:
This no doubt explains why there are two possible ways of seeing the figure

as a cube; and all similar phenomena. For we really see two different facts.
(If I look in the first place at the corner marked a and only glance at b, then a appears to be in front, and vice versa.)
sections.str: This also explains the sort of phenomena illustrated by this figure, which can be seen as a cube in two different ways. For we really see two different facts.(If I look in the first place at the corner marked a and only glance at b, then aappears to be in front, and vice versa.)

sections.ger: In der Logik ist nichts zufällig: Wenn das Ding im Sachverhalt vorkommen kann, so muß die Möglichkeit des Sachverhalts im Ding bereits präjudiziert sein.
sections.pmc: In logic nothing is accidental: if a thing can occur in a state of affairs, the possibility of the state of affairs must be written into the thing itself.
sections.str: In logic nothing is accidental: if a thing can occur in an elementary fact, it must already contain the possibility of that elementary fact.

sections.ger: Wenn die Dinge in Tatsachen vorkommen können, so muß dies schon in ihnen liegen.
sections.pmc: If things can occur in facts, this possibility must be in them from the beginning.
sections.str: If things can occur in facts, this possibility must already be within them.

sections.ger: Etwas Logisches kann nicht nur-möglich sein. Die Logik handelt von jeder Möglichkeit und alle Möglichkeiten sind ihre Tatsachen.
sections.pmc: Nothing in the province of logic can be merely possible. Logic deals with every possibility and all possibilities are its facts.
sections.str: Something logical cannot be merely possible. Logic deals with every possibility, and all possibilities are its facts.

sections.ger: Wie wir uns räumliche Gegenstände überhaupt nicht außerhalb des Raumes, zeitliche nicht außerhalb der Zeit denken können, so können wir uns keinen Gegenstand außerhalb der Möglichkeit seiner Verbindung mit anderen denken.
sections.pmc: Just as we are quite unable to imagine spatial objects outside space or temporal objects outside time, so too there is no object that we can imagine excluded from the possibility of combining with others.
sections.str: Just as we cannot think of spatial objects outside space nor temporal objects outside time, so we cannot think of any object outside the possibility of combining with others.

sections.ger: Wenn ich mir den Gegenstand im Verbande des Sachverhalts denken kann, so kann ich ihn nicht außerhalb der Möglichkeit dieses Verbandes denken.
sections.pmc: If I can imagine objects combined in states of affairs, I cannot imagine them excluded from the possibility of such combinations.
sections.str: If I can think of an object as part of an elementary fact, I cannot think of it without the possibility of such connections.

sections.ger: Es ist offenbar, daß auch eine von der wirklichen noch so verschieden gedachte Welt, etwas — eine Form — mit der wirklichen gemein haben muß.
sections.pmc: It is obvious that an imagined world, however different it may be from the real one, must have something - a form - in common with it.
sections.str: Obviously an imagined world, however different from the real world, must have something - a form - in common with it.

sections.ger: Die Art und Weise, wie die Gegenstände im Sachverhalt zusammenhängen ist die Struktur des Sachverhaltes.
sections.pmc: The determinate way in which objects are connected in a state of affairs is the structure of the state of affairs.
sections.str: The way in which objects are connected in an elementary fact is the structure of the elementary fact.

sections.ger: Die Sachverhalte sind von einander unabhängig. Aus dem Bestehen oder nicht Bestehen des Einen kann nicht auf das Bestehen oder nicht Bestehen des anderen geschlossen werden.
sections.pmc: From the existence or non-existence of the one it is impossible to infer the existence or non-existence of the other.
sections.str: From the obtaining or non-obtaining of the one it is impossible to infer the obtaining or non-obtaining of the other.

sections.ger: Man sagte einst daß Gott alles schaffen könne, nur nichts, was den logischen Gesetzten zuwider wäre. Wir könnten nämlich von einer 〟unlogischen" Welt nicht sagen wie sie aussähe.
sections.pmc: It used to be said that God could create anything except what would be contrary to the laws of logic. The reason being that we could not say what an 'illogical' world would look like.
sections.str: As the old saying goes: God can create anything so long as it does not contradict the laws of logic. The reason being that we could not say what an “illogical” world would look like.

sections.ger: Die Umgangssprache ist ein Teil des menschlichen Organismus und nicht weniger kompliziert als dieser.
sections.pmc: Everyday language is a part of the human organism and is no less complicated than it.
sections.str: Ordinary language is a part of the human organism and no less complicated than it.

sections.ger: Verneinung, Disjunktion, logische Multiplikation etc. sind Operationen.
sections.pmc: Negation, disjunction, logical multiplication, etc., are operations.
sections.str: Negation, disjunction, logical multiplication, etc., are operations.

sections.ger: Nur Operationen können verschwinden. (Wie z.B. die Verneinung in ~~p)
sections.pmc: Only operations can vanish (e.g. negation in ~~p).
sections.str: Only operations can vanish (e.g. negation in ~~p).

sections.ger: Und nur dies ist der Festsetzung wesentlich, daß sie nur eine Beschreibung von Zeichen ist und nichts über das Bezeichnete aussagt.
sections.pmc: And the only thing essential to the stipulation is that it is merely a description of signs and states nothing about what is signified.
sections.str: And all that is essential to the stipulation is that it merely describes the signs and states nothing about the signified.

sections.ger:
Ich definiere nun:
x = O0'x Def.
und |x, ξ, O'ξ| = |O0'x, Oν'ξ, Oν+1'ξ|
und O+1 = 1 Def.
also schreibe ich statt 〟x, O'x, O'O'x, O'O'O'x etc." 〟O0'x, O1'x, O1+1'x, O1+1+1'x, etc"
1+1 = 2 Def.
1+1+1 = 3 Def. u.s.w.
sections.pmc:
I give the following definitions:
x = O0'x Def.
and |x, ξ, O'ξ| = |O0'x, Oν'ξ, Oν+1'ξ|
and O+1 = 1 Def.
Therefore instead of 'x, O'x, O'O'x, O'O'O'x etc.', I write: 'O0'x, O1'x, O1+1'x, O1+1+1'x, etc.'
1+1 = 2 Def.;
1+1+1 = 3 Def.; etc.
sections.str: I give the following definitions:    x = O0'x Def. and 	|x, ξ, O'ξ | = |O 0'x , Oν'ξ , Oν+1'ξ| and 	           0+1 = 1 Def.Therefore in place of “x, O'x, O'O'x, O'O'O'x etc.”, I write: “O0'x, O1'x, O1+1'x, O1+1+1'x, etc.”     1+1 = 2 Def.;

sections.ger: Die Theorie der Klassen ist in der Mathematik ganz überflüssig. Dies hängt damit zusammen daß die Allgemeinheit die wir in der Mathematik brauchen nicht die 〟zufällige" ist.
sections.pmc:
The theory of classes is completely superfluous in mathematics.
This is connected with the fact that the generality required in mathematics is not 'accidental' generality.
sections.str: The theory of classes is entirely superfluous in mathematics. This is connected with the fact that the generality we need in mathematics is not an “accidental” one.

sections.ger: Eine zusammengesetzte Seele wäre nämlich keine Seele mehr.
sections.pmc: Indeed a composite soul would no longer be a soul.
sections.str: For a composite soul would no longer be a soul.

sections.ger: Mag das Ding noch so selbständig sein, was ja nichts heißt als daß es in allen möglichen Sachlagen vorkommen kann, so ist eben diese Form der Selbständigkeit eine Form des Zusammenhangs mit dem Sachverhalt, eine Form der Unselbständigkeit.
sections.pmc: However independent things may be - and this means no more than that they can occur in all possible situations - still this form of independence is a form of connection with states of affairs, a form of dependence.
sections.str: However independent things may be - and this means no more than that they can occur in all possible situations - still this form of independence is a form of connection with elementary facts, a form of dependence.

sections.ger:
Das kommt darauf hinaus, daß, im Falle Namen in — und außerhalb des Satzverbandes Bedeutung hätten, es sozusagen, nicht zu verbürgen wäre, daß sie in beiden Fällen wirklich dasselbe, im selben Sinne des Wortes, bedeuten.
Es scheint unmöglich zu sein, daß Worte in zwei verschiedenen Weisen auftreten, allein und im Satz.
sections.pmc:
What this comes to is that if it were the case that names had meaning both when combined in propositions and outside them, it would, so to speak, be impossible to guarantee that in both cases they really had the same meaning, in the same sense of the word.
It seems to be impossible for words to appear in two different roles: by themselves, and in propositions.
sections.str: What this comes to is that if it were the case that names had meaning both when combined in propositions and outside them, it would, so to speak, be impossible to guarantee that in both cases they really had the same meaning, in the same sense of the word. It seems to be impossible for words to appear in two different roles: alone, and in propositions.

sections.ger: Es erschiene gleichsam als Zufall wenn dem Ding, das allein für sich besteht, nachträglich eine Sachlage passen würde.
sections.pmc: It would seem to be a sort of accident, if it turned out that a situation would fit a thing that already existed entirely on its own.
sections.str: It would, so to speak, seem like an accident, if it turned out that a thing that could exist alone could be part of a situation.

sections.ger:
Wenn ich den Gegenstand kenne so kenne ich auch sämtliche Möglichkeiten seines Vorkommens in Sachverhalten.
Jede solche Möglichkeit muß in der Natur des Gegenstandes liegen.
sections.pmc:
If I know an object I also know all its possible occurrences in states of affairs.
Every one of these possibilities must be part of the nature of the object.
sections.str: If I know an object I also know all the possibilities of its occurrence in elementary facts. Every such possibility must lie in the nature of the object.

sections.ger: Es kann nicht nachträglich eine neue Möglichkeit gefunden werden.
sections.pmc: A new possibility cannot be discovered later.
sections.str: A new possibility cannot be found later on.

sections.ger: Sind alle Gegenstände gegeben so sind damit auch alle möglichen Sachverhalte gegeben.
sections.pmc: If all objects are given, then at the same time all possible states of affairs are also given.
sections.str: If all objects are given, then thereby all possible elementary facts are also given.

sections.ger: Diese feste Form besteht eben aus den Gegenständen.
sections.pmc: Objects are just what constitute this unalterable form.
sections.str: This fixed form consists of objects.

sections.ger: Die Substanz der Welt kann nur eine Form und keine materiellen Eigenschaften bestimmen. Denn diese werden erst durch die Sätze dargestellt — erst durch die Konfiguration der Gegenstände gebildet.
sections.pmc: The substance of the world can only determine a form, and not any material properties. For it is only by means of propositions that material properties are represented - only by the configuration of objects that are produced.
sections.str: The substance of the world can only determine a form, and not any material properties. Material properties can only be represented by means of propositions – they can only be produced by the configuration of objects.

sections.ger: Beiläufig gesprochen: Die Gegenstände sind farblos.
sections.pmc: In a manner of speaking, objects are colorless.
sections.str: Roughly speaking, objects are colourless.

sections.ger: Zwei Gegenstände von der gleichen logischen Form sind — abgesehen von ihren externen Eigenschaften — von einander nur dadurch unterschieden daß sie verschieden sind.
sections.pmc: If two objects have the same logical form, the only distinction between them, apart from their external properties, is that they are different.
sections.str: Two objects with the same logical form - apart from their external properties -  are only distinct from one another in that they are different.

sections.ger: Die Struktur der Tatsache besteht aus den Strukturen der Sachverhalte.
sections.pmc: The structure of a fact consists of the structures of states of affairs.
sections.str: The structure of a fact consists of the structures of its elementary facts.pt

sections.ger: Etwas 〟der Logik Widersprechendes" in der Sprache darstellen, kann man ebensowenig, wie in der Geometrie 〟eine den Gesetzen des Raumes widersprechende Figur" durch ihre Koordinaten darstellen, oder die Koordinaten eines 〟Punktes angeben welcher nicht existiert".
sections.pmc: It is as impossible to represent in language anything that 'contradicts logic' as it is in geometry to represent by its co-ordinates 'a figure that contradicts the laws of space', or to give the co-ordinates of 'a point that does not exist'.
sections.str: It is as impossible to say something that “contradicts logic” as it is to draw “a figure that contradicts the laws of space”, or to give the co-ordinates of “a point that does not exist”.

sections.ger: Wohl können wir einen Sachverhalt räumlich darstellen welcher den Gesetzen der Physik, aber keinen, der den Gesetzen der Geometrie zuwiderliefe.
sections.pmc: Though a state of affairs that would contravene the laws of physics can be represented to us spatially, one that would contravene the laws of geometry cannot.
sections.str: An elementary fact contradicting the laws of physics can be presented spatially, but not one that contradicts the laws of geometry.+ 43[2]	—		20.11.14 (1)The reality that corresponds to the sense of a proposition cannot be anything other than its constituent parts; since we are, surely, ignorant of everything else.

sections.ger: Es ist menschenunmöglich die Sprachlogik aus ihr unmittelbar zu entnehmen.
sections.pmc: It is not humanly possible to gather immediately from it what the logic of language is.
sections.str: It is not humanly possible to immediately extract the logic of language from it.

sections.ger: Eine Operation die aus einer Anzahl von Sätzen eine Wahrheitsfunktion dieser Sätze macht, nennen wir 〟Wahrheitsoperation" (W-Operation).
sections.pmc: An operation which, from a number of propositions, produces a truth-function of those propositions we call a truth-operation (T-Operation).
sections.str: An operation which, from a number of propositions, produces a truth-function of those propositions we call a truth-operation (T-operation).

sections.ger: Wie die Beschreibung der Sätze geschieht ist unwesentlich.
sections.pmc: How the description of the propositions is produced is not essential.
sections.str: The way in which the sentences are described is inessential.

sections.ger: Wir können drei Arten der Beschreibung unterscheiden: 1) Die direkte Aufzählung 2) Die Angabe einer Funktion F(x,y…) deren sämtliche Werte die zu beschreibenden Sätze sind 3) Die Angabe von Zügen welche jene Sätze charakterisieren.
sections.pmc: We can distinguish three kinds of description: 1. direct enumeration; 2. giving a function F(x, y, …) whose various values are the propositions to be described; 3. giving features which characterize those propositions.
sections.str: We can distinguish three kinds of description: 1. Direct enumeration. 2. Giving a function F (x , y, … ) whose various values are the propositions to be described. 3. Giving features which characterize those propositions.

sections.ger: Im ersten Fall können wir statt der Variablen einfach ihre (konstanten) Werte schreiben.
sections.pmc: In the first case instead of the variable we can simply write its (constant) values.
sections.str: In the first case we can simply replace the variable with its (constant) values.

sections.ger: Im zweiten Fall ist die Variable ein verallgemeinerter Satz.
sections.pmc: In the second case the variable is a generalized proposition.
sections.str: In the second case the variable is a generalized proposition.

sections.ger: Im dritten Falle sind die Werte der Variablen alle Sätze welche gewisse formale Eigenschaften besitzen.
sections.pmc: In the third case the values of the variable are all propositions that possess certain formal properties.
sections.str: In the third case the values of the variable are all propositions that possess certain formal properties.

sections.ger: Die allgemeine Form dieser Sätze kann nur durch die Form einer Variablen dargestellt werden.
sections.pmc: The general form of these propositions can be presented only by means of the form of a variable.
sections.str: The general form of these propositions can be presented only by means of the form of a variable.

sections.ger: Die richtige Theorie des Urteiles muß zeigen, daß es unmöglich ist einen Unsinn zu urteilen. (Russells Theorie genügt dieser Bedingung nicht.)
sections.pmc: The correct theory of judgment must show that it is impossible for a judgment to be a piece of nonsense. (Russell's theory does not satisfy this requirement.)
sections.str: The correct theory of judgment must show the impossibility of a judgment’s being a piece of nonsense. (Russell's theory does not satisfy this condition.)

sections.ger: Wenn ich mir ein Ding in einer Sachlage denken kann, dann kann ich es mir nicht außerhalb der Sachlage denken.
sections.pmc: If I can imagine a thing in a situation, then I cannot imagine it outside the situation.
sections.str: If I can imagine a thing in a situation, then I cannot imagine it out of the situation.

sections.ger: Um einen Gegenstand zu kennen brauche ich zwar nicht seine externen, aber ich muß alle seine internen Eigenschaften kennen.
sections.pmc: If I am to know an object though I need not know its external properties, I must know all its internal properties.
sections.str: To know an object, I need not know its external properties, but I must know all its internal properties.

sections.ger: Beiläufig gesprochen: Entweder ein Ding hat Eigenschaften die kein anderes hat, dann kann man es ohne weiteres durch eine Beschreibung aus den anderen herausheben und darauf hinweisen; oder aber es gibt mehrere Dinge, die ihre sämtlichen Eigenschaften gemeinsam haben, dann ist es überhaupt unmöglich auf eines zu zeigen. Denn ist das Ding durch nichts hervorgehoben, so kann ich es nicht hervorheben, denn sonst ist es eben hervorgehoben.
sections.pmc:
In a manner of speaking: either a thing has properties that nothing else has, in which case we can immediately use a description to distinguish it from the others and refer to it; or, on the other hand, there are several things that have the whole set of their properties in common, in which case it is quite impossible to indicate one.
For if there is nothing to distinguish a thing, I cannot distinguish it, since if I do it will be distinguished after all.
sections.str: In a manner of speaking: either a thing has unique properties, and then we can immediately use a description to distinguish it from others and refer to it; or, on the other hand, there are several things that have all their properties in common, in which case it is impossible to pick out one after all.For if there is nothing to distinguish a thing, I cannot distinguish it, for otherwise it would be distinguished after all.

sections.ger: Der sinnliche Ausdruck des Gedankens ist das Satzzeichen.
sections.pmc: The perceptible expression of a thought is a propositional sign.
sections.str: A sentential sign is a perceptible expression of a thought.

sections.ger: Das Satzzeichen ist eine Projektion des Gedankens.
sections.pmc: A propositional sign is a projection of a thought.
sections.str: A sentential sign is a projection of a thought.

sections.ger: Die Projektionsmethode ist die Art und Weise der Anwendung des Satzzeichens.
sections.pmc: The method of projection is the manner of applying the propositional sign.
sections.str: The way of applying the sentential sign is the method of projection.

sections.ger: Die Anwendung des Satzzeichens ist das Denken seines Sinns.
sections.pmc: Applying the propositional sign is [the same as] thinking of its sense.
sections.str: To apply the sentential sign is to think its sense.

sections.ger: Im Satzzeichen entsprechen den Gegenständen der Wirklichkeit die einfachen Zeichen.
sections.pmc: In a propositional sign the simple signs correspond to the objects of reality.
sections.str: In a sentential sign the simple signs correspond to the objects of reality.

sections.ger: Das Satzzeichen besteht darin, daß sich die einfachen Zeichen in ihm auf bestimmte Art und Weise zu einander verhalten.
sections.pmc: What constitutes a propositional sign is that in it the simple signs stand in a determinate relation to one another.
sections.str: What constitutes a sentential sign is that in it the simple signs stand in adeterminate relation to one another.pt

sections.ger: Das Satzzeichen ist eine Tatsache.
sections.pmc: A propositional sign is a fact.
sections.str: A sentential sign is a fact.

sections.ger: Sie verkleidet den Gedanken.
sections.pmc: It disguises thought.
sections.str: It disguises thought.

sections.ger: Und zwar so daß man nach der äußeren Form des Kleides nicht auf die Form des bekleideten Gedankens schließen kann; weil die äußere Form des Kleides nach ganz anderen Gesichtspunkten gebaut ist als nach dem, die Form des Körpers erkennen zu lassen.
sections.pmc: So much so, that from the outward form of the clothing it is impossible to infer the form of the thought beneath it, because the outward form of the clothing is not designed to reveal the form of the body, but with quite different things in view.
sections.str: So much so, that from the external form of the clothes one cannot infer the form of the thought beneath, because the external form of the clothes is designed not to reveal the form of the body, but from an entirely different perspective.

sections.ger: Fassen wir (F)(p) als Operationsresultat auf, so schreiben wir es 〟(F)'(p)"; und allgemein eine Operation auf 〟a" 〟b" 〟c"etc. O'(a,b,c, etc.).
sections.pmc: If we construe (F)(p) as the result of an operation we write it as '(F)'p'; and in general an operation on 'a', 'b', 'c', etc. is written as O'(a, b, c, etc.).
sections.str: If we construe (F)(p) as the result of an operation we write it as “(F)'p”; and in general an operation on “a”, “b”, “c”, etc. is written as O'(a, b, c, etc.).

sections.ger: Man muß es der Variablen selber ansehen wofür sie steht. — Es muß eine ganz bestimmte Ähnlichkeit zwischen ihr und ihrem Wert bestehen.
sections.pmc: It must appear from the variable itself what it stands for. - There must be a quite definite resemblance between it and its values.

sections.ger: Diese zweite Art der Verallgemeinerung die man die formale nennen kann ist von Russell und Frege übersehen worden.
sections.pmc: This second kind of generalization, which can be called the formal kind, was overlooked by Russell and Frege.
sections.str: This second kind of generalization, which can be called the formal kind, wasoverlooked by Russell and Frege.

sections.ger: Russells Darstellung ist unrichtig, sie enthält einen Circulus vitiosus.
sections.pmc: The way in which Russell presents it is incorrect: it contains a vicious circle.
sections.str: Russell’s presentation is incorrect: it contains a vicious circle.

sections.ger:
Der 〟Zahlbegriff" ist nichts anderes als das Gemeinsame aller Zahlzeichen; er ist die allgemeine Form der Zahl. 
Und der Begriff der Zahlengleichheit ist die allgemeine Form aller speziellen Zahlengleichheiten.
sections.pmc:
The 'concept of number' is simply what is common to all numerals; it is the general form of a number.
And the concept of numerical equality is the general form of all particular cases of numerical equality.
sections.str: The “concept of number” is simply what is common to all numerals, the general form of a number.And the concept of numerical equality is the general form of all particular cases of numerical equality.

sections.ger: Jedes Ding ist gleichsam in einem Raume möglicher Sachverhalte. Diesen Raum kann ich mir leer denken, nicht aber das Ding ohne den Raum.
sections.pmc: Each thing is, as it were, in a space of possible states of affairs. This space I can imagine empty, but I cannot imagine the thing without the space.
sections.str: Each thing is, as it were, in a space of possible elementary facts. I can imagine this space empty, but not the thing without the space.

sections.ger: Das Ding sei der materielle Punkt mit dem unendlichen Raum um sich. Es ist klar daß der materielle Punkt ohne den unendlichen Raum nicht denkbar ist.
sections.pmc: Suppose that things are point-masses with infinite space around them. Clearly a point-mass is unthinkable without infinite space.
sections.str: Suppose that things are point masses with infinite space around them. Clearly a point mass without infinite space is unthinkable.

sections.ger: Der Fleck im Gesichtsfeld muß zwar nicht rot sein aber eine Farbe muß er haben; er hat sozusagen den Farbenraum um sich. Der Ton muß eine Höhe haben der Gegenstand des Tastsinnes eine Härte etc.
sections.pmc: A speck in the visual field, though it need not be red, must have some color; it is, so to speak surrounded by color-space. Notes must have some pitch, objects of the sense of touch some degree of hardness, and so on.
sections.str: A spot in the visual field need not be red but it must have some colour; it is, so to speak, surrounded by colour-space. Notes must have some pitch, tactile objects some degree of hardness, and so on.

sections.ger: Die Substanz ist das, was unabhängig von dem, was der Fall ist, besteht.
sections.pmc: Substance is what subsists independently of what is the case.
sections.str: Substance is what persists independently of what is the case.

sections.ger: Es ist eine Projektion der Möglichkeit einer Sachlage.
sections.pmc: It is a projection of the possibility of a situation.
sections.str: It is a projection of the possibility of a situation.

sections.ger: Das einfache Zeichen bedeutet den Gegenstand. Er ist seine Bedeutung.
sections.pmc: A simple sign means an object. The object is its meaning.
sections.str: A simple sign means an object. The object is its meaning.

sections.ger: Nur Tatsachen können einen Sinn ausdrücken, eine Klasse von Namen kann es nicht.
sections.pmc: Only facts can express of a sense, a set of names cannot.
sections.str: Only facts can express a sense, a set of names cannot.

sections.ger: Daß das Satzzeichen eine Tatsache ist, wird durch die gewöhnliche Ausdrucksform der Schrift oder des Druckes verschleiert.
sections.pmc: Although a propositional sign is a fact, this is obscured by the usual form of expression in writing or print.
sections.str: That a sentential sign is a fact is concealed by the ordinary form of expression in writing or print.

sections.ger: So ist nach dem äußeren Schein der Umgangssprache jede Täuschung und Verwechselung möglich.
sections.pmc: Thus the outward aspect of ordinary language makes every kind of illusion and confusion possible.
sections.str: Thus the external aspect of ordinary language makes every kind of illusion and confusion possible.

sections.ger: 〟Existieren" erscheint als intransitives Verbum wie 〟gehen", 〟er ist" klingt wie 〟er ißt", 〟identisch" ist ein Eigenschaftswort und 〟Weiß" ein Personenname.
sections.pmc: 'Exist' figures as an intransitive verb like 'go'; 'you were' sounds like 'you wear'; 'identical' is an adjective; and 'White' is a proper name.
sections.str: “Exist” appears as an intransitive verb like “go”; “you were” sounds like “you wear”; “identical” is an adjective; and “White” is a proper name.

sections.ger: 〟 O' (a,b,c etc.)" ist das Operationsresultat, die Operation selber bezeichne ich mit 〟O'(ξ,η,ζ etc.)", wo die griechischen Buchstaben die Argumentstellen anzeigen.
sections.pmc: O'(a, b, c, etc.)' is the result of the operation. The operation itself I designate by 'O'(ξ, η, ζ, etc.)', in which the Greek letters indicate the argument-places.
sections.str: “O'(a, b, c, etc.)” is the result of the operation. The operation itself I designate by “O'(ξ, η, ζ, etc.)”, in which the Greek letters indicate the argument-places.

sections.ger: Diese zweite Art der Verallgemeinerung die man die formale nennen kann ist von Russell und Frege übersehen worden.
sections.pmc: This second kind of generalization, which can be called the formal kind, was overlooked by Russell and Frege.
sections.str: This second kind of generalization, which can be called the formal kind, wasoverlooked by Russell and Frege.

sections.ger: Der Zahlbegriff ist die variable Zahl.
sections.pmc: The concept of number is the variable number.
sections.str: The concept of number is the variable number.

sections.ger: Der Raumpunkt ist nach dieser Auffassung eine Argumentstelle.
sections.pmc: On this interpretation, a spatial point is an argument-place.
sections.str: On this conception, a point in space is an argument place.

sections.ger: Sie ist Form und Inhalt.
sections.pmc: It is form and content.
sections.str: It is form and content.

sections.ger: Raum und Zeit sind Formen der Gegenstände.
sections.pmc: Space and time are forms of objects.
sections.str: Space and time are forms of objects.

sections.ger: Ebenso ist die Farbe (oder Färbigkeit) eine Form der visuellen Gegenstände.
sections.pmc: In the same way color (being colored) is a form of visual objects.
sections.str: In the same way colour (being coloured) is a form of visual objects.

sections.ger: Der Satz ist kein Wörtergemisch. (Wie die Melodie kein Gemisch von Tönen)
sections.pmc: A proposition is not a medley of words. (Just as a tune is not a medley of notes.)
sections.str: A proposition is not a jumble of words. (Just as a tune is not a jumble of notes.)

sections.ger: Das musikalische Thema ist ein Satz.
sections.pmc: A theme in music is a proposition.
sections.str: A theme in music is a proposition.

sections.ger: Denn im gedruckten Satz z.B. sieht das Satzzeichen nicht wesentlich verschieden aus vom Wort.
sections.pmc: For in a printed proposition, for example, no essential difference is apparent between a propositional sign and a word.
sections.str: For in a printed sentence, for example, the sentential sign does not appear  essentially different from a word.

sections.ger: So war es möglich, daß Frege den Satz einen zusammengesetzten Namen nannte.
sections.pmc: That is what made it possible for Frege to call a proposition a composite name.
sections.str: That is what made it possible for Frege to call a proposition a compound name.

sections.ger: Nicht: 〟das komplexe Zeichen 〟aRb" sagt, daß a in der Beziehung R zu b steht", sondern: daß 〟a" in einer gewissen Beziehung zu 〟b" steht sagt, daß aRb.
sections.pmc: Instead of 'The complex sign "aRb" says that a stands to b in the relation R', we ought to put: That 'a' stands to 'b' in a certain relation says that aRb.
sections.str: Don’t say “The complex sign "aRb" says that a stands to b in the relation R”, but instead: That “a” stands to “b” in a certain relation says that aRb.

sections.ger: Die meisten Sätze und Fragen welche über philosophische Dinge geschrieben worden sind, sind nicht falsch, sondern unsinnig. Wir können daher Fragen dieser Art überhaupt nicht beantworten, sondern nur ihre Unsinnigkeit feststellen. Die meisten Fragen und Sätze der Philosophen beruhen darauf daß wir unsere Sprachlogik nicht verstehen.
sections.pmc: Most of the propositions and questions to be found in philosophical works are not false but nonsensical. Consequently we cannot give any answer to questions of this kind, but can only establish that they are nonsensical. Most of the propositions and questions of philosophers arise from our failure to understand the logic of our language.
sections.str: Most of the statements and questions philosophers have written are not false but nonsensical. So we cannot answer such questions at all, but can only point out their nonsensicality. Most of the questions and statements of philosophers result from not understanding the logic of our language.

sections.ger: Sie sind von der Art der Frage ob das Gute mehr oder weniger identisch ist als das Schöne.
sections.pmc: They belong to the same class as the question whether the good is more or less identical to the beautiful.
sections.str: They are of the same kind as the question whether the Good is more or less identical than the Beautiful.

sections.ger: Alle Philosophie ist 〟Sprachkritik". (allerdings nicht im Sinne Mauthners)
sections.pmc: All philosophy is a 'critique of language' (though not in Mauthner's sense).
sections.str: All philosophy is “critique of language” (though not at all in Mauthner's sense).

sections.ger: Russells Verdienst ist es gezeigt zu haben daß die scheinbare logische Form des Satzes nicht seine wirkliche sein muß.
sections.pmc: It was Russell who performed the service of showing that the apparent logical form of a proposition need not be its real one.
sections.str: Russell’s contribution is to have shown that the apparent logical form of a sentence need not be its real form.

sections.ger: Die fortgesetzte Anwendung einer Operation auf ihr eigenes Resultat, oder ihre eigenen Resultate, heißt ihre sukzessive Anwendung. (O'(O'(O'a)) ist das Resultat der (3-maligen) sukzessiven Anwendung von O'ξ auf a.)
sections.pmc: The repeated application of an operation to its own result or results is called the successive application of it. (O'(O'(O'a)) is the result of (three) successive applications of O'ξ to a.)
sections.str: The repeated application of an operation to its own result or results is called its successive application. (O'(O'(O'a)) is the result of (three) successive applications of O'ξ to a.)

sections.ger: Eine Funktion kann nicht ihr eigenes Argument sein, wohl aber kann das Resultat einer Operation ihre eigene Basis sein.
sections.pmc: A function cannot be its own argument, whereas an operation can take one of its own results as its base.
sections.str: A function cannot be its own argument, but the result of an operation can be its own basis.

sections.ger: So und nur so ist das Fortschreiten in der Hierarchie von einer Type zur anderen möglich.
sections.pmc: It is in this way and only in this way that the step from one type to another in the type hierarchy is possible.
sections.str: This is the only possible way of stepping from one type to another in the type hierarchy.

sections.ger: Russell und Whitehead haben die Möglichkeit dieses Fortschreitens nicht zugegeben aber immer wieder von ihr Gebrauch gemacht.
sections.pmc: Russell and Whitehead did not admit the possibility of such steps, but repeatedly availed themselves of it.
sections.str: Russell and Whitehead did not allow such steps, but they took them again and again.

sections.ger: Alle Sätze — z.B. — der Reihe: aRb,(Ex)·aRx·xRb,(Ex,y)·aRx·xRy·yRb, u.s.w. sind durch eine formale Eigenschaft charakterisiert.
sections.pmc: For example, all propositions of the series: aRb, (∃x). aRx . xRb, (∃x, y). aRx . xRy . yRb, etc. are characterized by a formal property.
sections.str: For example, all propositions of the series: aRb, (∃x).aRx.xRb, (∃x, y).aRx.xRy.yRb, etc. are characterized by a formal property.

sections.ger: Die Sätze der Logik sind die Tautologien.
sections.pmc: The propositions of logic are the tautologies.
sections.str: The propositions of logic are the tautologies.

sections.ger: Die Satze der Logik sagen also nichts. Sie sind die analytischen Sätze.
sections.pmc: Therefore the propositions of logic say nothing. They are the analytic propositions.
sections.str: Therefore the propositions of logic say nothing. They are the analytic propositions.

sections.ger: Theorien die einen Satz der Logik sehr gehaltvoll erscheinen lassen, sind immer falsch. Die Worte 〟Wahr" und 〟Falsch" z.B. scheinen zwei Eigenschaften unter anderen Eigenschaften zu bezeichnen, und da scheint es eine sehr merkwürdige Tatsache zu sein daß jeder Satz eine dieser Eigenschaften hat. Das scheint nun nichts weniger als selbstverständlich, ebensowenig selbstverständlich wie etwa der Satz 〟alle Rosen sind entweder gelb oder rot" klänge, auch wenn er wahr wäre. Ja, jener Satz bekommt nun ganz den Charakter eines naturwissenschaftlichen Satzes, und dies ist das sichere Anzeichen dafür, daß er falsch aufgefaßt wurde.
sections.pmc: All theories that make a proposition of logic appear to have a large amount of content are false. For example, the words 'true' and 'false' seem to signify two properties among other properties, and then it seems to be a remarkable fact that every proposition has one of these properties. On this theory it seems to be anything but obvious, just as, for instance, the proposition 'All roses are either yellow or red' would not sound obvious even if it were true. Indeed, the logical proposition acquires all the characteristics of a proposition of natural science and this is the sure sign that it has been construed wrongly.
sections.str: Theories that make a proposition of logic appear to have a large amount of content are always false. For example, the words “true” and “false” seem to signify two properties among other properties, and then it seems to be a remarkable fact that every proposition has one of these properties. This now seems to be no more obvious than the proposition “All roses are either yellow or red” would seem, even if it were true. Indeed, the logical proposition acquires all the characteristics of a proposition of natural science, and this is a sure sign that it has been wrongly construed.

sections.ger: Die richtige Erklärung der logischen Sätze, muß ihnen eine einzigartige Stellung unter allen Sätzen geben.
sections.pmc: The correct explanation of the propositions of logic must assign to them a unique status among all propositions.
sections.str: The correct explanation of logical propositions must give them a unique position among all propositions.

sections.ger: Die Erforschung der Logik bedeutet die Erforschung aller Gesetzmäßigkeit. Und außerhalb der Logik ist alles Zufall.
sections.pmc: The exploration of logic means the exploration of everything that is subject to law. And outside logic everything is accidental.
sections.str: The investigation of logic means the investigation of all that is subject to law. And outside logic, all is accident.

sections.ger: Nur wenn es Gegenstände gibt, kann es eine feste Form der Welt geben.
sections.pmc: There must be obejcts, if the world is to have an unalterable form.
sections.str: Only if there are objects, can the world have a fixed form.

sections.ger: Der Satz ist artikuliert.
sections.pmc: A proposition is articulated.
sections.str: A proposition is articulate.

sections.ger: Sehr klar wird das Wesen des Satzzeichens, wenn wir es uns, statt aus Schriftzeichen, aus räumlichen Gegenständen (aus Tischen, Stühlen Büchern etc.) zusammensetzen.
sections.pmc: The essence of a propositional sign is very clearly seen if we imagine one composed of spatial objects (such as tables, chairs, books) instead of written signs.
sections.str: The essence of a sentential sign becomes very clear if we consider one made up not of written signs but of spatial objects (such as tables, chairs, books).

sections.ger: Der Satz ist ein Bild der Wirklichkeit.
sections.pmc: A proposition is a picture of reality.
sections.str: A proposition is a picture of reality.

sections.ger: Dies sehen wir daraus, daß wir den Sinn des Satzzeichens verstehen, ohne daß er uns erklärt wurde.
sections.pmc: We can see this from the fact that we understand the sense of a propositional sign without its having been explained to us.
sections.str: We can see this from the fact that we understand the sense of a 	sentential sign without its having been explained to us.

sections.ger: Die Bedeutungen der einfachen Zeichen der Wörter müssen uns erklärt werden damit wir sie verstehen.
sections.pmc: The meanings of simple signs, words, must be explained to us if we are to understand them.
sections.str: The meanings of simple signs (words), must be explained to us if we are tounderstand them.

sections.ger: Mit den Sätzen aber verständigen wir uns.
sections.pmc: With propositions, however, we make ourselves understood.
sections.str: But we make ourselves understood with propositions.

sections.ger: Es liegt im Wesen des Satzes, daß er uns einen uns(?) neuen Sinn mitteilen kann.
sections.pmc: It belongs to the essence of a proposition that it should be able to communicate to us a sense which is new to us?.
sections.str: It is essential to a proposition that it be able to communicate a new sense to us.

sections.ger: Ein Satz muß mit alten Ausdrücken einen neuen Sinn mitteilen.
sections.pmc: A proposition must use old expressions to communicate a new sense.
sections.str: A proposition must communicate a new sense with old words.

sections.ger: Der Satz teilt uns eine Sachlage mit, also muß er wesentlich mit dieser Sachlage zusammenhängen.
sections.pmc: A proposition communicates a situation to us, and so it must be essentially connected with that situation.
sections.str: A proposition communicates a situation to us, and so it must be 		essentially connected with that situation.

sections.ger: Und der Zusammenhang ist eben, daß er ihr logisches Bild ist.
sections.pmc: And the connection is precisely that it is its logical picture.
sections.str: And the connection is precisely that it is its logical picture.

sections.ger: Die Wirklichkeit wird mit dem Satz verglichen.
sections.pmc: Reality is compared with propositions.
sections.str: Reality is compared with propositions.

sections.ger: Nur dadurch kann der Satz wahr oder falsch sein, indem er ein Bild der Wirklichkeit ist.
sections.pmc: A proposition can be true or false only in virtue of being a picture of reality.
sections.str: A proposition can be true or false only by being a picture of reality.

sections.ger: Die Operation kann erst dort auftreten wo ein Satz auf logisch bedeutungsvolle Weise aus einem anderen entsteht, also schon, und erst, wo die logische Konstruktion des Satzes anfängt.
sections.pmc: Operations cannot make their appearance before the point at which one proposition is generated out of another in a logically meaningful way; i.e. when and only when the logical construction of propositions begins.
sections.str: Operations can first arise when one proposition is generated out of another in a logically meaningful way; i.e. when and only when the logical construction of propositions begins.

sections.ger: Es ist das besondere Merkmal der logischen Sätze daß man am Symbol allein erkennen kann, daß sie wahr sind, und diese Tatsache schließt die ganze Philosophie der Logik in sich. Und so ist es auch eine der wichtigsten Tatsachen daß sich die Wahrheit oder Falschheit der nicht-logischen Sätze nicht am Satz allein erkennen läßt.
sections.pmc: It is the peculiar mark of logical propositions that one can recognize that they are true from the symbol alone, and this fact contains in itself the whole philosophy of logic. And so too it is a very important fact that the truth or falsity of non-logical propositions cannot be recognized from the propositions alone.
sections.str: It is the characteristic mark of logical propositions that one can recognize that they are true from the symbol alone, and this fact contains in itself the whole philosophy of logic. And so too it is one of the most important facts that the truth or falsity of nonlogical propositions cannot be recognized from the propositions alone.

sections.ger: Dürfen denn die Gesetze der Logik selbst wieder logischen Gesetzen unterstehen?
sections.pmc: Or is it possible for the laws of logic to be subject in their turn to logical laws?
sections.str: Or is it possible for the laws of logic in their turn to obey logical laws?

sections.ger: Das Feste, das Bestehende und der Gegenstand sind eins.
sections.pmc: Objects, the unalterable, and the subsistent are one and the same.
sections.str: Objects, the fixed, and the persistent are one.

sections.ger: Der Gegenstand ist das Feste, Bestehende; die Konfiguration ist das Wechselnde, Unbeständige.
sections.pmc: Objects are what is unalterable and subsistent; their configuration is what is changing and unstable.
sections.str: Objects are what is fixed and persistent; their configuration is what is changing and variable.

sections.ger: Die Konfiguration der Gegenstände bildet den Sachverhalt.
sections.pmc: The configuration of objects produces states of affairs.
sections.str: The configuration of objects forms an elementary fact.	 4.091	28[3]	 4.061 (1)		AüL 194 (3)**If one does not notice that propositions make sense independently of the facts, one can easily believe that true and false are relations of equal value between signs and what they signify.

sections.ger: Tatsachen kann man nicht benennen.
sections.pmc: Facts cannot be given names.
sections.str: Facts cannot be named.

sections.ger: Die gegenseitige räumliche Lage dieser Dinge drückt dann den Sinn des Satzes aus.
sections.pmc: Then the spatial arrangement of these things will express the sense of the proposition.
sections.str: Then the spatial arrangement of these things expresses the sense of the proposition.

sections.ger: Die Möglichkeit aller Gleichnisse, der ganzen Bildhaftigkeit unserer Ausdrucksweise, ruht in der Logik der Abbildung.
sections.pmc: The possibility of all imagery, of all our pictorial modes of expression, is contained in the logic of depiction.
sections.str: The possibility of all similes, of all the imagery of our language, rests on the logic of depiction.

sections.ger: Auf den ersten Blick scheint der Satz — wie er etwa auf dem Papier gedruckt steht — kein Bild der Wirklichkeit zu sein, von der er handelt.
sections.pmc: At first sight a proposition - one set out on the printed page, for example - does not seem to be a picture of the reality with which it is concerned.
sections.str: At first sight a sentence – say as it is set out on the printed page – does not seem to be a picture of the reality it is about.

sections.ger: Aber auch die Notenschrift scheint auf den ersten Blick kein Bild der Musik zu sein und unsere Lautzeichen- (Buchstaben-) Schrift kein Bild unserer Lautsprache.
sections.pmc: But no more does musical notation at first sight seem to be a picture of music, nor our phonetic notation (the alphabet) to be a picture of our speech.
sections.str: But neither does musical notation at first sight seem to be a picture of music, nor our phonetic notation (the letters of the alphabet) to be a picture of our spoken language.

sections.ger: Und doch erweisen sich diese Zeichensprachen auch im gewöhnlichen Sinne als Bilder dessen was sie darstellen.
sections.pmc: And yet these sign-languages prove to be pictures, even in the ordinary sense, of what they represent.
sections.str: And yet these sign-languages turn out to be pictures, even in the ordinary sense, of what they represent.

sections.ger: Und wenn wir in das Wesentliche dieser Bildhaftigkeit eindringen, so sehen wir, daß dieselbe durch scheinbare Unregelmäßigkeiten (wie die Verwendung der musicinline ♯ und musicinline ♭ in der Notenschrift) nicht gestört wird.
sections.pmc: And if we penetrate to the essence of this pictorial character, we see that it is not impaired by apparent irregularities (such as the use of ♯ and ♭ in musical notation).
sections.str: And if we penetrate to the essence of this pictorial character, we see that it is not hindered by apparent irregularities (such as the use of ♯ and ♭ in musical notation).pt

sections.ger: Denn auch diese Unregelmäßigkeiten bilden das ab was sie ausdrücken sollen, nur auf eine andere Art und Weise.
sections.pmc: For even these irregularities depict what they are intended to express; only they do it in a different way.
sections.str: For even these irregularities depict what they are to express, only in a different way.

sections.ger: Um das Wesen des Satzes zu verstehen, denken wir an die Hieroglyphenschrift, die eingestandenermaßen die Tatsachen, welche sie beschreibt, abbildet.
sections.pmc: In order to understand the essential nature of a proposition, we should consider hieroglyphic script, which avowedly depicts the facts it describes.
sections.str: To understand the essence of a proposition, consider hieroglyphic writing, which admittedly depicts the facts it describes.

sections.ger: Und aus ihr wurde die Buchstabenschrift, ohne das Wesentliche der Abbildung zu verlieren.
sections.pmc: And alphabetic script developed out of it without losing what was essential to depiction.
sections.str: And from it came alphabetic writing, without losing what was essential to depiction.

sections.ger: Der Satz ist ein Bild der Wirklichkeit; denn ich kenne die von ihm dargestellte Sachlage, wenn ich den Satz verstehe. Und den Satz verstehe ich, ohne daß mir sein Sinn erklärt wurde.
sections.pmc: A proposition is a picture of reality: for if I understand a proposition, I know the situation that it represents. And I understand the proposition without having had its sense explained to me.
sections.str: A proposition is a picture of reality: for if I understand a proposition, I know the situation that it represents. And I understand the proposition without its sense having been explained to me.

sections.ger: Der Satz sagt nur insoweit etwas aus als er ein Bild ist.
sections.pmc: A proposition states something only in so far as it is a picture.
sections.str: A proposition asserts something only insofar as it is a picture.

sections.ger: Im Satz wird gleichsam eine Sachlage probeweise zusammengestellt.
sections.pmc: In a proposition a situation is, as it were, constructed by way of experiment.
sections.str: In a proposition a situation is, as it were, put together as an experiment.

sections.ger: Man kann geradezu sagen: statt, dieser Satz hat diesen und diesen Sinn; dieser Satz stellt diese und diese Sachlage dar.
sections.pmc: Instead of, 'This proposition has such and such a sense', we can simply say, 'This proposition represents such and such a situation'.
sections.str: Instead of “This proposition has such and such a sense”, one can say “This proposition represents such and such a situation”.

sections.ger: Beachtet man nicht daß der Satz einen von den Tatsachen unabhängigen Sinn hat, so kann man leicht glauben daß wahr und falsch gleichberechtigte Bezeichnungen von Zeichen und Bezeichnetem sind.
sections.pmc: It must not be overlooked that a proposition has a sense that is independent of the facts: otherwise one can easily suppose that true and false are relations of equal status between signs and what they signify.

sections.ger: (Man könnte dann z.B. sagen, daß 〟p" auf die wahre Art bezeichnet was 〟~p" auf die falsche Art. etc.)
sections.pmc: (In that case one could say, for example, that 'p' signified in the true way what '~p' signified in the false way, etc.)
sections.str: (One could then say, for instance, that “p” truly signifies what “~p” falsely signifies, etc.).

sections.ger: Den Elementarsatz können wir als Wahrheitsfunktion seiner selbst auffassen.
sections.pmc: We can regard an elementary proposition as a truth-function of itself.
sections.str: We can regard an elementary proposition as a truth-function of itself.

sections.ger:
Die Wahrheitsfunktionen einer bestimmten Anzahl von Sätzen lassen sich in einem Schema folgender Art hinschreiben:
Wir nennen es das Schema II.
sections.pmc:
The truth-functions of a given number of elementary propositions can always be set out in a schema of the following kind:
We call it Schema No. II.
sections.str: The truth-functions of a given number of elementary propositions can always be set out in a schema of the following kind: We call it Schema No. II.

sections.ger: Diejenigen Wahrheitsmöglichkeiten der W-Argumente, welche den Satz bewahrheiten nenne ich seine Wahrheitsgründe.
sections.pmc: I give the name truth-grounds to those truth-possibilities of its T-arguments that make it true.
sections.str: I give the name “truth-grounds” to those truth-possibilities of a proposition’s truth-arguments that make it true.

sections.ger: Sind die Wahrheitsgründe einer Anzahl von Sätzen sämtlich auch Wahrheitsgründe eines bestimmten Satzes so sagen wir die Wahrheit dieses Satzes folge aus der Wahrheit der Gesamtheit jener anderen.
sections.pmc: If all the truth-grounds of a number of propositions are at the same time truth-grounds of another proposition, then we say that the truth of that proposition follows from the truth of the totality of those propositions.
sections.str: If the truth-grounds common to several propositions are also truth-grounds of a certain proposition, then we say that the truth of that proposition follows from the truth of the totality of those propositions.

sections.ger: Folgt p aus q und q aus p, so sind sie ein und derselbe Satz.
sections.pmc: If p follows from q and q from p, then they are one and the same proposition.
sections.str: If p follows from q and q follows from p, then they are one and the same proposition.

sections.ger: Folgt ein Satz aus einem anderen, so sagt dieser mehr als jener, jener weniger als dieser.
sections.pmc: If one proposition follows from another, the latter says more than the former, and the former less than the latter.
sections.str: If a proposition follows from another, then the latter says more than the former, and the former says less than the latter.

sections.ger: Die Tautologie folgt aus allen Sätzen; sie sagt nichts.
sections.pmc: A tautology follows from all propositions; it says nothing.
sections.str: A tautology follows from all propositions: it says nothing.

sections.ger: Die Kontradiktion ist das Gemeinsame der Sätze, was kein Satz mit einem anderen gemein hat. Die Tautologie ist das Gemeinsame aller Sätze welche nichts mit einander gemein haben.
sections.pmc: Contradiction is that common factor of propositions which no proposition has in common with another. Tautology is the common factor of all propositions that have nothing in common with one another.
sections.str: Contradiction is what propositions have in common that no proposition has in common with another. Tautology is what all propositions have in common that have nothing in common with one another.

sections.ger: Folgt ein Satz aus einem anderen so gibt dieser jenem die Wahrscheinlichkeit 1. Sind zwei Sätze von einander unabhängig, so gibt jeder dem anderen die Wahrscheinlichkeit ½.
sections.pmc: If one proposition follows from another, then the latter proposition gives to the former the probability 1. If two propositions are independent of one another, then each gives to the other the probability 1/2.
sections.str: If one proposition follows from another, then the latter gives the former the probability 1. If two propositions are independent of one another, then each gives the other the probability ½.

sections.ger: Daß sie Tautologien sind, das zeigt die formalen — logischen — Eigenschaften der Sprache, der Welt.
sections.pmc: The fact that they are tautologies shows the formal - logical - properties of language and the world.
sections.str: That they are tautologies shows the formal - logical - properties of language, of the world.

sections.ger: Daraus ergibt sich daß die logischen Sätze nicht unbedingt notwendig sind da wir ja in einer entsprechenden Notation diestrukturellen Eigenschaften der Sätze durch das bloße Ansehen dieser Sätze erkennen können.
sections.pmc: It follows from this that logical propositions are not unconditionally necessary; for in a suitable notation we can in fact recognize the structural properties of propositions by mere inspection of the propositions themselves.
sections.str: It follows from this that logical propositions are not unconditionally necessary; for in a suitable notation we can in fact recognize the structural properties of the propositions merely by inspecting them.

sections.ger: Die Logik ist keine Lehre sondern ein Spiegelbild der Welt.
sections.pmc: Logic is not a body of doctrine, but a mirror-image of the world.
sections.str: Logic is not a theory, but a mirror image of the world.

sections.ger: Die Tatsachen begreifen wir in Bildern.
sections.pmc: Facts are grasped by us in pictures.
sections.str: We grasp facts by way of pictures.

sections.ger: Das Bild stellt die Sachlage im logischen Raum, das Bestehen und nicht Bestehen von Sachverhalten, vor.
sections.pmc: A picture presents a situation in logical space, the existence and non-existence of states of affairs.
sections.str: A picture presents a situation in logical space, the obtaining or non-obtaining of elementary facts.

sections.ger: Das Bild ist ein Modell der Wirklichkeit.
sections.pmc: A picture is a model of reality.
sections.str: A picture is a model of reality.

sections.ger: Den Gegenständen entsprechen im Bild die Elemente des Bildes.
sections.pmc: In a picture objects have the elements of the picture corresponding to them.
sections.str: In a picture the elements of the picture correspond to the objects.

sections.ger: Das Bild besteht darin, daß sich seine Elemente in bestimmter Art und Weise zu einander verhalten.
sections.pmc: What constitutes a picture is that its elements are related to one another in a determinate way.
sections.str: A picture consists in its elements being combined in a definite way.

sections.ger: Das Bild ist eine Tatsache.
sections.pmc: A picture is a fact.
sections.str: A picture is a fact.

sections.ger: Die Tatsache muß, um Bild zu sein, etwas mit dem Abgebildeten gemeinsam haben.
sections.pmc: If a fact is to be a picture, it must have something in common with what it depicts.
sections.str: A fact will count as a picture only if it has something in common with what it represents.

sections.ger: Was das Bild mit der Wirklichkeit gemein haben muß um sie auf seine Art und Weise — richtig oder falsch — abbilden zu können ist seine Form der Abbildung.
sections.pmc: What a picture must have in common with reality, in order to be able to depict it - correctly or incorrectly - in the way it does, is its pictorial form.
sections.str: What a picture must have in common with reality, to be able to depict it - correctly or incorrectly - in the way it does, is its form of depiction.

sections.ger: Was jedes Bild welcher Form immer mit der Wirklichkeit gemein haben muß um sie überhaupt — richtig oder falsch — abbilden zu können ist die logische Form, das ist die Form der Wirklichkeit.
sections.pmc: What any picture, of whatever form, must have in common with reality, in order to be able to depict it - correctly or incorrectly - in any way at all, is logical form, i.e. the structure of reality.
sections.str: What any picture, of whatever form, must have in common with reality,  be able to depict it - correctly or incorrectly - in any way at all, is logical form, i.e. the structure of reality.

sections.ger: Das logische Bild kann die Welt abbilden.
sections.pmc: Logical pictures can depict the world.
sections.str: Logical pictures can depict the world.

sections.ger: Das Satzzeichen mit der Art und Weise seiner Abbildung ist der Satz.
sections.pmc: A propositional sign with its mode of depiction is a proposition.
sections.str: A proposition is a sentential sign plus its mode of depiction.

sections.ger: Die im Satze angewandten einfachen Zeichen heißen Namen.
sections.pmc: The simple signs employed in propositions are called names.
sections.str: The simple signs employed in propositions are called names.

sections.ger: Nur der Satz hat Sinn, nur im Zusammenhang des Satzes hat ein Name Bedeutung.
sections.pmc: Only propositions have sense, only in the nexus of a proposition does a name have a meaning.
sections.str: Only propositions make sense, only in the context of a proposition is a name meaningful.

sections.ger: Die Möglichkeit des Satzes basiert auf dem Prinzip der Vertretung von Gegenständen durch Zeichen.
sections.pmc: The possibility of propositions is based on the principle that objects have signs as their representatives.
sections.str: The possibility of propositions is based on the principle that objects are  represented by their signs.

sections.ger: Offenbar ist, daß wir einen Satz in der Form aRb als Bild empfinden.
sections.pmc: It is obvious that a proposition strikes us as a picture when it is in the form aRb.
sections.str: Obviously, a proposition the form aRb looks like a picture.

sections.ger:
Die Grammophonplatte, der musikalische Gedanke, die Notenschrift, die Schallwellen, stehen alle in jener abbildenden internen Beziehung zu einander die zwischen Sprache und Welt besteht.
Ihnen allen ist der logische Bau gemeinsam.
sections.pmc:
A gramophone record, the musical idea, the written notes, and the sound-waves, all stand to one another in the same internal relation of depicting that holds between language and the world.
They are all constructed according to a common logical pattern.
sections.str: The gramophone record, the musical thought, the score, the sound waves, all stand to one another in that internal pictorial relation which holds between language and the world. They all have a common logical structure.

sections.ger: Wie im Märchen die zwei Jünglinge, ihre zwei Pferde und ihre Lilien. Sie sind alle in gewissem Sinne eins.
sections.pmc: Like the two youths in the fairy-tale, their two horses, and their lillies. They are all in a certain sense one.
sections.str: Like the two youths, their two horses, and their lilies in the fairy tale. In a certain sense, they are all one.

sections.ger: Der Satz zeigt seinen Sinn.
sections.pmc: A proposition shows its sense.
sections.str: A proposition shows its sense.

sections.ger: Nur insoweit ist der Satz ein Bild einer Sachlage als er logisch gegliedert ist.
sections.pmc: It is only in so far as a proposition is logically segmented that it is a picture of a situation.
