sections.str: A proposition is a picture of a situation only insofar as it is logically articulated.

sections.ger: Auch der Satz 〟ambulo" ist zusammengesetzt, denn sein Stamm ergibt mit einer anderen Endung und seine Endung mit einem anderen Stamm einen anderen Sinn.
sections.pmc: Even the proposition, Ambulo, is composite: for its stem with a different ending yiled a different sense, and so does its ending with a different stem.
sections.str: Even the Latin proposition “Ambulo” is composite: for with another ending its stem yields a different sense, as does its ending with another stem.

sections.ger:
〟Kann man sich nicht mit falschen Sätzen, wie bisher mit wahren verständigen? solange man nur weiß daß sie falsch gemeint sind."
Nein! Denn wahr ist ein Satz wenn es sich so verhält wie wir es durch ihn sagen; und wenn wir mit 〟q" ~q meinen und es sich so verhält wie wir es meinen so ist 〟q" in der neuen Auffassung wahr und nicht falsch.
sections.pmc:
Can we not make ourselves understood with false propositions just as we have done up till now with true ones? So long as it is known that they are meant to be false.
No! For a proposition is true if we use it to say that things stand in a certain way, and they do; and if by 'q' we mean ~q and things stand as we mean that they do, then, construed in the new way, 'q' is true and not false.
sections.str: “Can we not make ourselves understood with false propositions just as we have done up to now with true ones, so long as we know that they are meant to be false?”

sections.ger: Die Elementarsätze sind die Wahrheitsargumente (W-Argumente) des Satzes.
sections.pmc: Elementary propositions are the truth-arguments (T-arguments) of propositions.
sections.str: Elementary propositions are the truth-arguments of propositions.

sections.ger: Die Wahrheitsfunktionen lassen sich in Reihen ordnen.
sections.pmc: Truth-functions can be arranged in series.
sections.str: Truth-functions can be arranged in series.

sections.ger: Insbesondere folgt die Wahrheit eines Satzes p aus der Wahrheit eines anderen q wenn alle Wahrheitsgründe des ersten Wahrheitsgründe des zweiten sind.
sections.pmc: In particular, the truth of a proposition p follows from the truth of another proposition q if all the truth-grounds of the former are truth-grounds of the latter.

sections.ger: Wir sagen auch die Wahrheitsgründe des einen sind in denen des anderen enthalten, p folge aus q.
sections.pmc: We also say the truth-grounds of the one are contained in those of the other: p follows from q.
sections.str: We also say the truth-grounds of the one are contained in those of the other: p follows from q.

sections.ger: Folgt p aus q so ist der Sinn von p im Sinne von q enthalten.
sections.pmc: If p follows from q, the sense of p is contained in the sense of q.
sections.str: If p follows from q, the sense of p is contained in the sense of q.

sections.ger: Der Satz bejaht jeden Satz der aus ihm folgt.
sections.pmc: A proposition affirms every proposition that follows from it.
sections.str: A proposition affirms every proposition that follows from it.

sections.ger: Zwei Sätze sind einander entgegengesetzt wenn es keinen sinnvollen Satz gibt der sie beide bejaht.
sections.pmc: Two propositions are opposed to one another if there is no proposition with a sense, that affirms them both.
sections.str: Two propositions oppose each other if there is no meaningful proposition  that affirms both.

sections.ger: Jeder Satz der einem anderen widerspricht verneint ihn.
sections.pmc: Every proposition that contradicts another negates it.
sections.str: Every proposition that contradicts another negates it.

sections.ger: Die Kontradiktion verschwindet sozusagen außerhalb, die Tautologie innerhalb aller Sätze.
sections.pmc: Contradiction, one might say, vanishes outside all propositions: tautology vanishes inside them.
sections.str: Contradiction vanishes so to speak outside all propositions, tautology inside them.

sections.ger: Das Folgen ist ein Grenzfall des Wahrscheinlich-gemacht-Werdens.
sections.pmc: Following from is a limiting case of being made probable.
sections.str: Following from is a limiting case of being made probable.

sections.ger: Daß ihre Bestandteile so verknüpft eine Tautologie ergeben, das charakterisiert die Logik ihrer Bestandteile.
sections.pmc: The fact that a tautology is yielded by this particular way of connecting its constituents characterizes the logic of its constituents.
sections.str: The fact that a tautology is yielded by this way of connecting its constituents characterizes the logic of its constituents.

sections.ger: Die Logik ist transzendental.
sections.pmc: Logic is transcendental.
sections.str: Logic is transcendental.

sections.ger: Die Elemente des Bildes vertreten im Bild die Gegenstände.
sections.pmc: In a picture the elements of the picture are the representatives of objects.
sections.str: A picture’s elements stand, in the picture, for the objects.pt

sections.ger: Daß sich die Elemente des Bildes in bestimmter Art und Weise zu einander verhalten, stellt vor daß sich die Sachen so zu einander verhalten.
sections.pmc: The fact that the elements of a picture are related to one another in a determinate way represents that things are related to one another in the same way.
sections.str: The definite way in which the picture elements go together represents how things are related to one another.

sections.ger: Dieser Zusammenhang der Elemente des Bildes heißt seine Form der Abbildung.
sections.pmc: This connection of the elements of a picture is called its pictorial form.
sections.str: This connection of the elements of a picture is called its form of depiction.

sections.ger: In Bild und Abgebildetem muß etwas identisch sein, damit das eine überhaupt ein Bild des anderen sein kann.
sections.pmc: There must be something identical in a picture and what it depicts, to enable the one to be a picture of the other at all.
sections.str: Only if a picture and what it depicts contain something identical can the former be a picture of the latter.pt

sections.ger: Es gibt verschiedene Formen der Abbildung.
sections.pmc: There are various pictorial forms.
sections.str: There are various forms of depiction.

sections.ger: Ist die Form der Abbildung die logische Form so heißt das Bild das logische Bild.
sections.pmc: A picture whose pictorial form is logical form is called a logical picture.
sections.str: A picture whose form of depiction is logical form is called a logical picture.

sections.ger: Die Forderung der einfachen Zeichen ist die Forderung der Bestimmtheit des Sinnes.
sections.pmc: The requirement that there be simple signs is the requirement that sense be determinate.
sections.str: The demand for simple signs is the demand that sense be determinate.

sections.ger: Namen gleichen Punkten, Sätze Pfeilen, sie haben Sinn.
sections.pmc: Names are like points; propositions like arrows - they have sense.
sections.str: Names are like points; propositions like arrows - they have sense.

sections.ger: Namen lassen sich nicht definieren, sie sind Urzeichen.
sections.pmc: Names are indefinable; they are primitive signs.
sections.str: Names are indefinable; they are primitive signs.

sections.ger: Jedes definierte Zeichen bezeichnet über jene Zeichen durch welche es definiert wurde. Und die Definitionen weisen den Weg. Zwei Zeichen, ein Urzeichen und ein definiertes Zeichen, können nie auf dieselbe Weise bezeichnen. Namen kann man nicht definieren. Man kann überhaupt kein Zeichen definieren, welches allein, selbständig eine Bedeutung hat.
sections.pmc: Every sign that has a definition signifies via the signs that serve to define it. And the definitions point the way. Two signs cannot signify in the same manner if one is primitive and the other is a defined sign. Names cannot be defined - nor in general, can any sign that has a meaning independently and on its own.
sections.str: Every defined sign signifies via the signs by which it is defined; the definitions point the way. Two signs, one primitive and one defined, cannot signify in the same way. Names cannot be defined - nor in general, can any sign that has a meaning independently and on its own.

sections.ger: Die Bedeutungen von Urzeichen können durch Erläuterungen erklärt werden. Erläuterungen sind Sätze, welche die Urzeichen enthalten. Sie können also nur verstanden werden, wenn die Bedeutungen dieser Zeichen bereits bekanntsind.
sections.pmc: The meanings of primitive signs can be explained by means of elucidations. Elucidations are propositions that contain the primitive signs. So they can only be understood if the meanings of those signs are already known.
sections.str: The meanings of primitive signs can be explained by means of elucidations. Elucidations are propositions containing the primitive signs. So they can only be understood if the meanings of those signs are already known.

sections.ger: Mein Grundgedanke ist, daß die 〟logischen Konstanten" nicht vertreten. Daß sich die Logik der Tatsachen nicht vertreten läßt.
sections.pmc: My fundamental idea is that the 'logical constants' are not representatives; that there can be no representatives of the logic of facts.
sections.str: My fundamental thought is that the “logical constants” are not representatives; that the logic of facts cannot be represented.

sections.ger: Hier ist die Bezeichnungsweise offenbar ein Gleichnis des Bezeichneten.
sections.pmc: In this case the mode of signification is obviously a likeness of what is signified.
sections.str: Here the mode of signification is obviously a likeness of the signified.

sections.ger: Der Satz zeigt, wie es sich verhält, wenn er wahr ist.
sections.pmc: A proposition shows how things stand if it is true.
sections.str: A proposition shows how things stand, if it is true.

sections.ger: Die Wirklichkeit muß durch den Satz auf ja oder nein fixiert sein; dazu muß sie durch ihn vollständig beschreiben werden.
sections.pmc: A proposition must restrict reality to two alternatives: yes or no; in order to do that, it must describe reality completely.
sections.str: A proposition must restrict reality to two alternatives: yes or no. To do that, it must describe reality completely.

sections.ger: Der Satz ist die Beschreibung eines Sachverhalts.
sections.pmc: A proposition is a description of a state of affairs.
sections.str: A proposition is a description of an elementary fact.

sections.ger: Am Satz muß geradesoviel zu unterscheiden sein als an der Sachlage die er darstellt.
sections.pmc: In a proposition there must be exactly as many distinguishable parts as in the situation that it represents.
sections.str: In a proposition there must be exactly as many distinguishable parts as in the situation that it represents.

sections.ger: Daß aber die Zeichen 〟q" und 〟~q" das gleiche sagen können ist wichtig. Denn es zeigt daß dem Zeichen 〟~" in der Wirklichkeit nichts entspricht.
sections.pmc: But it is important that the signs 'q' and '~q' can say the same thing. For it shows that nothing in reality corresponds to the sign '~'.
sections.str: But it is important that the signs “p” and “~p” can say the same thing. For it shows that the sign “~” corresponds to nothing in reality.

sections.ger: Daß in einem Satz die Verneinung vorkommt ist noch kein Merkmal seines Sinnes. ( ~~p=p).
sections.pmc: The occurrence of negation in a proposition is not enough to characterize its sense (~~p = p).
sections.str: That negation occurs in a proposition is not a characteristic mark of its sense (~~p = p).

sections.ger: Die Sätze p und ~p haben entgegengesetzten Sinn aber es entspricht ihnen eine und dieselbe Wirklichkeit.
sections.pmc: The propositions 'p' and '~p' have opposite sense, but there corresponds to them one and the same reality.
sections.str: The propositions “p” and “~p” have opposite senses, but one and the same reality corresponds to them.

sections.ger: Es liegt nahe die Argumente von Funktionen mit den Indexen von Namen zu verwechseln. Ich erkenne nämlich sowohl am Argument wie am Index die Bedeutung des sie enthaltenden Zeichens. In Russells 〟+c" ist z.B. 〟c" ein Index der darauf hinweist daß das ganze Zeichen das Additionszeichen für Kardinalzahlen ist. Aber dies beruht auf einer willkürlichen Übereinkunft und man könnte statt 〟+c" auch ein einfaches Zeichen wählen: in 〟~p" aber ist 〟p" nicht ein Index sondern ein Argument; der Sinn von 〟~p" kann nicht verstanden werden ohne daß vorher der Sinn von p verstanden worden wäre. Im Namen 〟Julius Cäsar" ist 〟Julius" ein Index. (Der Index ist immer ein Teil einer Beschreibung des Gegenstandes dessen Namen wir ihm anhängen. (Der Cäsar aus dem Geschlecht der Julier.))
sections.pmc: The arguments of functions are readily confused with the affixes of names. For both arguments and affixes enable me to recognize the meaning of the signs containing them. For example, when Russell writes '+c', the 'c' is an affix which indicates the sign as a whole is the addition-sign for cardinal numbers. But that is the result of an arbitrary convention and it would be quite possible to choose a simple sign instead of '+c'; in '~p', however, 'p' is not an affix but an argument; the sense of '~p' cannot be understood unless the sense of p has been understood already. In the name 'Julius Caesar' 'Julius' is an affix. (An affix is always part of a description of the object to whose name we attach it. (The Caesar of the Julian gens.))
sections.str: It is quite natural to confuse the arguments of functions with the indexes of names. For I recognize equally well from the argument and the index what is meant by the signs containing them. In Russell’s “+c”, for instance, “c” is an index indicating that the whole  sign is the addition sign for cardinal numbers. But that is due to an arbitrary convention and we could have chosen a simple sign instead of “+c”; in “~p”, however, “p” is not an index but an argument; the sense of “~p” cannot be understood unless one already understands the sense of p. In the name “Julius Caesar” “Julius” is an index. (An index is always part of a description of the object to whose name we attach it. (The Caesar of the Julian gens.))

sections.ger: Das ist die Grundlage der Wahrscheinlichkeitslehre.
sections.pmc: That is the foundation of the theory of probability.
sections.str: That is the foundation for the theory of probability.

sections.ger: Wenn ein Gott eine Welt erschafft, worin gewisse Sätze wahr sind, so schafft er damit auch schon eine Welt in welcher alle Folgesätze stimmen. Und ähnlich könnte er keine Welt schaffen worin der Satz p wahr ist ohne seine sämtlichen Gegenstände zu schaffen.
sections.pmc: If a god creates a world in which certain propositions are true, then by that very act he also creates a world in which all the propositions that follow come true. And similarly he could not create a world in which the proposition p was true without creating all its objects.
sections.str: If a god creates a world in which certain propositions are true, he thereby creates a world in which all the propositions that follow from them are true. And similarly he could not create a world in which proposition p was true without creating all its objects.

sections.ger: 〟p·q" ist einer der Sätze welche 〟p" bejahen und zugleich einer der Sätze welche 〟q" bejahen.
sections.pmc: 'p.q' is one of the propositions that affirm 'p' and at the same time one of the propositions that affirm 'q'.
sections.str: “p.q” is one of the propositions that affirm “p” while also being one of the propositions that affirm “q”.

sections.ger: Die Kontradiktion ist die äußere Grenze der Sätze, die Tautologie ist ihr substanzloser Mittelpunkt.
sections.pmc: Contradiction is the outer limit of propositions: tautology is the unsubstantial point at their centre.
sections.str: Contradiction is the outer limit of propositions, tautology their substanceless centre.

sections.ger: So ist die Wahrscheinlichkeit eine Verallgemeinerung.
sections.pmc: It is in this way that probability is a generalization.
sections.str: Thus probability is a generalization.

sections.ger: Damit Sätze auf bestimme Art und Weise verknüpft eine Tautologie ergeben, dazu müssen sie bestimmte Eigenschaften der Struktur haben. Daß sie so verbunden eine Tautologie ergeben zeigt also daß sie diese Eigenschaften der Struktur besitzen.
sections.pmc: If propositions are to yield a tautology when they are connected in a certain way, they must have certain structural properties. So their yielding a tautology when combined in this way shows that they possess these structural properties.
sections.str: If propositions are to yield a tautology when they are connected in a certain way, they must have certain structural properties. That they yield a tautology when combined in this way shows therefore that they possess these structural properties.

sections.ger: Daß z.B. p und ~p einander widersprechen zeigt sich an der Tautologie 〟~(p·~p)".
sections.pmc: For example, the fact that p and ~p contradict one another is manifest in the tautology '~(p.~p)'.
sections.str: For example, that p and ~p contradict one another shows itself in the tautology “~(p .~p)”.
It is now clear that there need not be, as Russell thought, a special 'law of contradiction' for each 'type'; rather, that one law is enough, since it need not be applied to itself.

sections.ger: Ergeben z.B. zwei Sätze p und q in der Verbindung p ⊃ q eine Tautologie so ist klar daß dann q aus p folgt. Daß z.B. 〟q" aus 〟p ⊃ q·p" folgt ersehen wir aus jenen beiden Sätzen selbst aber wir können es auch so zeigen indem wir sie zu 〟p ⊃ q·p .⊃. q" verbinden und nun zeigen daß dies eine Tautologie ist.
sections.pmc:
If, for example, two propositions p and q in the combination p⊃q yield a tautology, then it is clear in that case q follows from p.
For example, we see from the two propositions themselves that 'q' follows from 'p⊃q.p', but it is also possible to show it in this way: we combine them to form 'p⊃q.p.⊃.q', and then show that this is a tautology.
sections.str: If, for example, two propositions p and q combine in p⊃q to yield a tautology, then clearly q follows from p. For instance, that “q” follows from “p⊃q.p” can be seen from the two propositions themselves, but we can also show it by combining them to form “p⊃q.p.⊃.q”, and then showing that this is a tautology.

sections.ger: Die logischen Sätze demonstrieren die logischen Eigenschaften der Sätze indem sie sie zu nichtssagenden Sätzen verbinden.
sections.pmc: Logical propositions demonstrate the logical properties of propositions by combining them so as to form propositions that say nothing.
sections.str: Logical propositions demonstrate the logical properties of propositions, by combining them into propositions that say nothing.

sections.ger: Diese Methode könnte man auch eine Nullmethode nennen: Im logischen Satz werden Sätze mit einander in's Gleichgewicht gebracht und der Zustand des Gleichgewichts zeigt dann an wie diese Sätze logisch beschaffen sein müssen.
sections.pmc: This method could also be called a zero-method. In a logical proposition, propositions are brought into equilibrium with one another, and the state of equilibrium then indicates what the logical constituttion of these propositions must be.
sections.str: This method could also be called a zero-method. In a logical proposition, propositions are brought into equilibrium with one another, and the state of equilibrium then shows how these propositions must be logically composed.

sections.ger: Der sinnvolle Satz sagt etwas aus, und sein Beweis zeigt daß es so ist; in der Logik ist jeder Satz die Form eines Beweises.
sections.pmc: A proposition that has sense states something, which is shown by its proof to be so. In logic every proposition is the form of a proof.
sections.str: A proposition that has sense says that something is the case, and its proof shows that it is so. In logic every proposition is the form of a proof.

sections.ger: Jeder logische Satz ist ein in Zeichen dargestellter Modus ponens. (Und den Modus ponens kann man nicht durch einen Satz ausdrücken).
sections.pmc: Every logical proposition is a modus ponens represented in signs. (And one cannot express the modus ponens by means of a proposition.)
sections.str: Every logical proposition is a modus ponens represented in signs. (And the modus ponens cannot be expressed by a proposition.)

sections.ger: Nun wird klar warum man oft fühlte, als wären die 〟logischen Wahrheiten" von uns zu 〟fordern": wir können sie nämlich insofern fordern als wir eine genügende Notation fordern können.
sections.pmc: Now it becomes clear why people have often felt as if it were for us to 'postulate' the 'truths of logic'. The reason is that we can postulate them in so far as we can postulate an adequate notation.
sections.str: Now it becomes clear why people have often felt as though “logical truths” must be “postulated” by us. Namely, we can postulate them in so far as we can postulate an adequate notation.

sections.ger: Es wird jetzt auch klar warum die Logik die Lehre von den Formen und vom Schließen genannt wurde.
sections.pmc: It also becomes clear why logic was called the theory of forms and of inference.
sections.str: Now it also becomes clear why logic was called the theory of forms and of inference.

sections.ger: Das Bild hat mit dem Abgebildeten die logische Form der Abbildung gemein.
sections.pmc: A picture has logico-pictorial form in common with what it depicts.
sections.str: What a picture shares with what it depicts is the logical form of depiction.

sections.ger: Das Bild bildet die Wirklichkeit ab, indem es eine Möglichkeit des Bestehens und nicht Bestehens von Sachverhalten darstellt.
sections.pmc: A picture depicts reality by representing a possibility of existence and non-existence of states of affairs.
sections.str: A picture depicts reality by representing a possibility of existence and non-existence of elementary facts.

sections.ger: Das Bild stellt eine mögliche Sachlage im logischen Raum dar.
sections.pmc: A picture represents a possible situation in logical space.
sections.str: A picture represents a possible situation in logical space.

sections.ger: Das Bild enthält die Möglichkeit der Sachlage, die es darstellt.
sections.pmc: A picture contains the possibility of the situation that it represents.
sections.str: A picture contains the possibility of the situation that it represents.

sections.ger: Das Bild ist so mit der Wirklichkeit verknüpft, es reicht bis zu ihr.
sections.pmc: That is how a picture is attached to reality; it reaches right out to it.
sections.str: In this way a picture makes contact with, or reaches out to, reality.

sections.ger: Das Bild kann jede Wirklichkeit abbilden, deren Form es hat.
sections.pmc:
A picture can depict any reality whose form it has.
A spatial picture can depict anything spatial, etc.
sections.str: A picture can depict any reality whose form it has. A spatial picture, anything spatial, etc.

sections.ger: Jedes Bild ist auch ein logisches. (Dagegen ist z.B. nicht jedes Bild ein räumliches.)
sections.pmc: Every picture is at the same time a logical one. (On the other hand, not every picture is, for example, a spatial one.)
sections.str: Every picture is also a logical one. (On the other hand, not every picture is, for example, a spatial one.)

sections.ger: Die Analyse der Zeichen muß einmal zu einem Ende kommen, weil die Zeichen, wenn sie überhaupt etwas ausdrücken sollen, auf eine ein für allemal fertige Weise bedeuten müssen.
sections.pmc: The analysis of signs must come to an end at some point, because if signs are to express anything at all, meaning must belong to them in a way that is once and for all complete.
sections.str: The analysis of signs must come to an end at some point, because if signs are to express anything at all, meaning must belong to them in a way that is once and for all complete.

sections.ger: Es kann nie das gemeinsame Merkmal zweier Gegenstände anzeigen, daß wir sie mit demselben Namen, aber durch zwei verschiedene Bezeichnungsweisen bezeichnen. Denn der Name ist ja willkürlich; man könnte also auch zwei verschiedene Namen wählen, und wo bliebe dann das Gemeinsame in der Bezeichnung.
sections.pmc:
It can never indicate the common characteristic of two objects that we designate them by the same name but by means of two different modes of designation.
For the name, of course, is arbitrary. So we could choose two different names instead, and then what would be left in common on the signifying side?
sections.str: Signifying two objects by the same name but using two different modes of signification can never indicate a common characteristic. For the name is of course arbitrary. So we could choose two different names instead, and then where would there be what was in common in the signifying?

sections.ger: Den Satz sowie jeden Teil eines solchen, nenne ich kurz 〟Symbol".
sections.pmc: For the sake of brevity I call a proposition as well as any part of a proposition a symbol.
sections.str: To put it concisely: I call a proposition as well as any part of a proposition a symbol.

sections.ger: Jedes Symbol ist ein Satz oder ein Teil eines Satzes also das was Sätze mit einander gemein haben.
sections.pmc: Every symbol is a proposition or a part of a proposition: thus symbols are what propositions can have in common with one another.
sections.str: Every symbol is a proposition or a part of a proposition: thus symbols are what propositions have in common with one another.

sections.ger: Obwohl jedes Wort über seine Definitionen bedeutet so heißt das doch nur so viel, daß diese Definitionen nötig sind um in der Zeichensprache darzustellen, wie der Gedanke den das Wort ausdrücken hilft, durch die Sprache vollständig abgebildet wird. Die Definitionen können aber auch verschwiegen werden und das Wort verliert dadurch seine Bedeutung nicht, denn es steht ja trotzdem in derselben Beziehung zu den Gegenständen, die durch die Definition abgebildet wird, nur daß wir diese Beziehung nicht eigens abbilden. Hierdurch wird natürlich die Zeichensprache oft vereinfacht, ihr Verständnis immer erschwert, denn das Maßgebende liegt nun außerhalb der Zeichen in der nicht ausgedrückten Beziehung zu ihren Gegenständen.
sections.pmc: Although every word has meaning via its definitions, this only means that these definitions are necessary in order to present in our sign-language the full linguistic depiction of the thought to whose expression the word contributes. But the definitions can be left tacit and the word does not then lose its meaning, since it still stands in the same relation to the objects which are depicted by means of the definitions - only we do not specifically depict that relation. Naturally this often simplifies the sign-language and makes the understanding of it more and more difficult, because the decisive factor now lies outside the signs in something that is not expressed - their relation to their objects.
sections.str: Although every word has meaning via its definitions, this only means that these definitions are necessary to present in our sign language the full linguistic depiction of the thought to whose expression the word contributes. But the definitions can be left tacit and the word does not then lose its meaning, since it still stands in the same relation to the objects depicted by means of the definitions - only we do not specifically depict that relation. Naturally this often simplifies the sign language and makes understanding it much harder, for the decisive factor now lies outside the signs in the unstated relation to their objects.

sections.ger: Der Satz stellt das Bestehen und nicht Bestehen der Sachverhalte dar.
sections.pmc: Propositions represent the existence and non-existence of states of affairs.
sections.str: A proposition represents the obtaining or non-obtaining of elementary facts.

sections.ger: Die Gesamtheit der wahren Sätze ist die Weltbeschreibung.
sections.pmc: The totality of true propositions is the description of the world.
sections.str: The totality of true propositions is a world description.pt

sections.ger: Und er sagt, daß es sich so verhält.
sections.pmc: And it says that they do so stand.
sections.str: And it says that that is how they are.

sections.ger: Wie die Beschreibung eines Gegenstandes nach seinen externen Eigenschaften so beschreibt der Satz die Wirklichkeit nach ihren internen Eigenschaften.
sections.pmc: Just as a description of an object describes it by giving its external properties, so a proposition describes reality by its internal properties.
sections.str: Just as a description describes an object by its external properties, so a proposition describes reality by its internal properties.

sections.ger: Die beiden müssen die gleiche logische (mathematische) Mannigfaltigkeit besitzen. (Vergl. Hertz' 〟Mechanik")
sections.pmc: The two must possess the same logical (mathematical) multiplicity. (Compare Hertz's Mechanics.)
sections.str: They must both possess the same logical (mathematical) multiplicity. (Compare Hertz's Mechanics.)

sections.ger: Diese mathematische Mannigfaltigkeit kann man natürlich nicht selbst wieder abbilden, da jedes Bild von ihr diese Mannigfaltigkeit selbst besitzen muß. Aus ihr kann man beim Abbilden nicht heraus.
sections.pmc: This mathematical multiplicity, of course, cannot itself be the subject of depiction because any picture of it must itself possess that multiplicity. One cannot get away from it when depicting.
sections.str: Naturally, this mathematical multiplicity cannot itself be depicted because any picture of it must have that multiplicity itself. One cannot get away from it when depicting.

sections.ger:
Wollten wir das, was wir durch 〟(x)·fx" ausdrücken, z.B. durch Vorsetzen eines Indexes vor 〟fx" ausdrücken — etwa so 〟Alg·fx", es würde nicht genügen — wir wüßten nicht was verallgemeinert wurde.
Wollten wir es durch einen Index am 〟x" anzeigen — etwa so 〟f(xa)" — es würde auch nicht genügen — wir wüßten nicht den Bereich der Allgemeinheitsbezeichnung.
Wollten wir es durch Einführen einer Marke in die Argumentstellen versuchen — etwa so 〟(A,A)·F(A,A)" — es würde nicht genügen — wir könnten die Identität der Variablen nicht feststellen — u.s.w.
Alle diese Bezeichnungsweisen genügen nicht, weil sie nicht die notwendige mathematische Mannigfaltigkeit haben.
sections.pmc:
If we wanted to express what we now write as '(x).fx', say, by putting an affix in front of 'fx' - for instance by writing 'Gen.fx' - it would not be adequate: we should not know what was being generalized.
If we wanted to signalize it with an affix attached to the 'x' - for instance by writing '(xg)' - that would not be adequate either: we should not know the scope of the generality-sign.
If we were to try to do it by introducing a mark into the argument places -for instance, by writing '(G, G).F(G, G)' - it would not be adequate: we should not be able to establish the identity of the variables. And so on.
All these modes of signifying are inadequate because they lack the necessary mathematical multiplicity.
sections.str: If we wanted to express what is expressed by “(x).fx”, say by putting an index in front of “fx” such as “Gen.fx” - it would not work, for we would not know what was generalized.If we tried to indicate it by adding an index to the “x” - for instance by writing “f(xg)” – it still would not work, for we would not know the scope of the generality sign.If we tried to do it by introducing a mark into the argument places – such as “(G, G).F (G, G)” - it would not work: we could not determine the identity of the variables. And so on.All these ways of signifying are inadequate because they do not have the necessary mathematical multiplicity.

sections.ger: Aus demselben Grund genügt die idealistische Erklärung des Sehens der räumlichen Beziehungen durch die 〟Raumbrille" nicht, weil sie nicht die Mannigfaltigkeit dieser Beziehungen erklären kann.
sections.pmc: For the same reason the idealist's appeal to 'spatial spectacles' is inadequate to explain the seeing of spatial relations, because it cannot explain the multiplicity of these relations.
sections.str: Likewise, the idealist's explanation of the seeing of spatial relations through “spatial glasses” does not work, because it cannot explain the multiplicity of these relations.

sections.ger:
Ein Bild zur Erklärung des Wahrheitsbegriffes: Schwarzer Fleck auf weißem Papier. Die Form des Fleckes kann man beschreiben indem man für jeden Punkt der Fläche angibt, ob er weiß oder schwarz ist. Der Tatsache daß ein Punkt schwarz ist entspricht eine positive — der, daß ein Punkt weiß (nicht schwarz) ist eine negative Tatsache. Bezeichne ich einen Punkt der Fläche (einen Fregeschen Wahrheitswert), so entspricht dies der Annahme die zur Beurteilung aufgestellt wird etc. etc.
Um aber sagen zu können ein Punkt sei schwarz oder weiß, muß ich vorerst wissen wann man einen Punkt schwarz und wann man ihn weiß nennt; um sagen zu können 〟p" ist wahr (oder falsch) muß ich bestimmt haben unter welchen Umständen ich p wahr nenne, und damit bestimme ich den Sinn des Satzes.
Der Punkt an dem das Gleichnis hinkt ist nun der: Wir können auf einen Punkt des Papiers zeigen auch ohne zu wissen was weiß und schwarz ist; einem Satz ohne Sinn aber entspricht gar nichts, denn er bezeichnet kein Ding (Wahrheitswert) dessen Eigenschaften etwa 〟falsch" oder 〟wahr" hießen; das Verbum eines Satzes ist nicht 〟ist wahr" oder 〟ist falsch" — wie Frege glaubte —, sondern das was 〟wahr ist" muß das Verbum schon enthalten.
sections.pmc:
An analogy to illustrate the concept of truth: imagine a black spot on white paper. You can describe the shape of the spot by saying, for each point on the sheet, whether it is black or white. To the fact that a point is black there corresponds a positive fact, and to the fact that a point is white (not black), a negative fact. If I designate a point on the sheet (a truth-value according to Frege), then this corresponds to the supposition that is put forward for judgment, etc. etc.
But in order to be able to say that a point is black or white, I must first know when a point is called black, and when white: in order to be able to say, 'p' is true (or false), I must have determined in what circumstances I call p true, and in so doing I determine the sense of the proposition.
Now the point where the simile breaks down is this: we can indicate a point on the paper even if we do not know what black and white are, but if a proposition has no sense, nothing corresponds to it, since it does not designate a thing (a truth-value) which might have properties called 'false' or 'true'. The verb of a proposition is not 'is true' or 'is false', as Frege thought: rather, that which 'is true' must already contain the verb.
sections.str: An analogy to illustrate the concept of truth.  A black spot on white paper; the form of the spot can be described by saying for each point on the sheet whether it is black or white. To the fact that a point is black there corresponds a positive fact, and to the fact that a point is white (not black), a negative fact. If I designate a point on the sheet (a Fregean truth-value), then this corresponds to the supposition that is put forward for judgment, etc. etc.However, to be able to say that a point is black or white, I must first know when a point is called black, and when white: I cannot say “p” is true (or false) unless I have determined in what circumstances I call p true, and in so doing I determine the sense of the proposition.Now the point where the simile breaks down is this: we can pick a point on the paper even if we don’t know what black and white are, but if a sentence makes no sense, nothing at all corresponds to it, for it designates no thing (a truth-value) which might have properties called “false” or “true”. The verb of a proposition is not “is true” or “is false”, as Frege thought: rather, that which “is true” must already contain the verb.

sections.ger: Die Verwechslung von Argument und Index liegt, wenn ich mich nicht irre, der Theorie Freges von der Bedeutung der Sätze und Funktionen zugrunde. Für Frege waren die Sätze der Logik Namen und deren Argumente die Indexe dieser Namen.
sections.pmc: If I am not mistaken, Frege's theory about the meaning of propositions and functions is based on the confusion between an argument and an affix. Frege regarded the propositions of logic as names, and their arguments as the affixes for those names.
sections.str: If I am not mistaken, Frege's theory about the meaning of propositions and functions is based on the confusion between an argument and an index. For Frege the propositions of logic are names and their arguments are the indexes for those names.

sections.ger: Sei in einem Schema II Wr die Anzahl der 〟W" in der Kolonne des Satzes r; Wrs die Anzahl derjenigen 〟W" in der Kolonne des Satzes s die in gleichen Reihen mit 〟W" in der Kolonne von r stehen. Der Satz 〟r" gibt dann dem Satz s die Wahrscheinlichkeit Wrs/Wr.
sections.pmc: In a schema like II, let Tr be the number of 'T's' in the column of the proposition r, and let Trs be the number of 'T's' in the column of the proposition s that stand in rows in which the column of the proposition r has 'T's'. Then the proposition 'r' gives to the proposition s the probability Trs/Tr.
sections.str: In a schema like II, let Tr be the number of “T's” in the column of the proposition r, and let Trs be the number of “T's” in the column of the proposition s that stand in rows in which the column of the proposition r has “T's”. Then the proposition “r” gives to the proposition s the probability Trs/Tr.

sections.ger: Daß ein Satz aus einem anderen folgt, ersehen wir aus der Struktur der Sätze.
sections.pmc: When one proposition follows from another, we can see this from the structure of the propositions.
sections.str: That one proposition follows from another we see from the structure of the propositions.

sections.ger: Folgt p aus q so kann ich aus q auf p schließen, p aus q folgern.
sections.pmc: If p follows from q, I can make an inference from q to p, deduce p from q.
sections.str: If p follows from q, I can infer from q to p, deduce p from q.

sections.ger: Die Art des Schlusses ist allein aus den beiden Sätzen zu entnehmen.
sections.pmc: The nature of inference can be gathered only from the two propositions.
sections.str: The method of inference can only be drawn from the two propositions.

sections.ger: Nur sie selbst können den Schluß rechtfertigen.
sections.pmc: They themselves are the only possible justification of the inference.
sections.str: Only they themselves can justify the inference.

sections.ger: Alles Folgern geschieht a priori.
sections.pmc: All deductions are made a priori.
sections.str: All deductions takes place a priori.

sections.ger: Sie involviert eine allgemeine Beschreibung einer Satzform.
sections.pmc: It involves a general description of a propositional form.
sections.str: It involves a general description of a propositional form.

sections.ger: Nur in Ermanglung der Gewißheit gebrauchen wir die Wahrscheinlichkeit. Wenn wir zwar eine Tatsache nicht vollkommen kennen aber wohl etwas über ihre Form wissen.
sections.pmc: We use probability only in default of certainty - if our knowledge of fact is not indeed complete, but we do know something about its form.
sections.str: We use probability only in place of certainty - if our knowledge of a fact is incomplete, but we do know something about its form.

sections.ger: Es gibt keine besondere logische Konstante die den Wahrscheinlichkeitssätzen eigen wäre.
sections.pmc: There is no special logical constant peculiar to probability propositions.
sections.str: There is no special logical constant unique to probability propositions.

sections.ger: Der Wahrscheinlichkeitssatz ist gleichsam ein Auszug aus Elementarsätzen.
sections.pmc: A probability proposition is a sort of excerpt from elementary propositions.
sections.str: A probability proposition is, as it were, an excerpt from elementary propositions.

sections.ger: Was sich in den Sätzen über Wahrscheinlichkeit durch das Experiment bestätigen läßt kann nicht Mathematik sein.
sections.pmc: Anything in propositions about probability that can be confirmed by experiment cannot be mathematical.
sections.str: Anything in propositions about probability that can be confirmed by experiment cannot be mathematical.

sections.ger: Es ist klar daß man zu demselben Zweck statt der Tautologien auch die Kontradiktionen verwenden könnte.
sections.pmc: It is clear that one could achieve the same purpose by using contradictions instead of tautologies.
sections.str: Clearly we could have used for this purpose contradictions instead of tautologies.

sections.ger: Dies wirft ein Licht auf die Frage, warum die logischen Sätze nicht durch die Erfahrung bestätigt werden können ebensowenig wie sie durch die Erfahrung widerlegt werden können. Nicht nur muß ein Satz der Logik durch keine mögliche Erfahrung widerlegt werden können, sondern er darf auch nicht durch eine solche bestätigt werden können.
sections.pmc: This throws some light on the question why logical propositions cannot be confirmed by experience any more than they can be refuted by it. Not only must a proposition of logic be irrefutable by any possible experience, it must also be unconfirmable by any possible experience.
sections.str: This throws light on the question why logical propositions can no more be confirmed by experience than they can be refuted by it. Not only must a proposition of logic be  incapable of being contradicted by any possible experience, it must likewise be unconfirmable by any possible experience.

sections.ger: Das Bild stimmt mit der Wirklichkeit überein oder nicht; es ist richtig oder unrichtig, wahr oder falsch.
sections.pmc: A picture agrees with reality or fails to agree; it is correct or incorrect, true or false.
sections.str: A picture agrees with reality or fails to agree; it is correct or incorrect, true or false.

sections.ger: Das Bild stellt dar, was es darstellt, unabhängig von seiner Wahr- oder Falschheit, durch die Form der Abbildung.
sections.pmc: What a picture represents it represents independently of its truth or falsity, by means of its pictorial form.
sections.str: A picture represents what it represents, independently of its truth or falsehood, by means of its form of depiction.

sections.ger: Es ist wie ein Maßstab an die Wirklichkeit angelegt.
sections.pmc: It is laid against reality like a measure.
sections.str: It is applied to reality like a ruler.

sections.ger: Nur die äußersten Punkte der Teilstriche berühren den zu messenden Gegenstand.
sections.pmc: Only the end-points of the graduating lines actually touch the object that is to be measured.
sections.str: Only the end points of the marks on the ruler touch the object being measured.

sections.ger: Seine Form der Abbildung aber kann das Bild nicht abbilden; es weist sie auf.
sections.pmc: A picture cannot, however, depict its pictorial form: it displays it.
sections.str: A picture cannot, however, depict its form of depiction: it displays it.

sections.ger: Man könnte die Bestimmtheit auch so fordern: Wenn ein Satz Sinn haben soll, so muß vorerst die syntaktische Verwendung jedes seiner Teile festgelegt sein. — Man kann z.B. nicht erst nachträglich daraufkommen, daß ein Satz aus ihm folgt. Sondern, welche Sätze aus ihm folgen muß vollkommen feststehen, ehe dieser Satz einen Sinn haben kann.
sections.pmc: The requirement of determinateness could also be formulated in the following way: if a proposition is to have sense, the syntactical employment of each of its parts must have been established in advance. For example, if cannot occur to one only subsequently that a certain proposition follows from it. Before a proposition can have a sense, it must be completely settled what propositions follow from it.
sections.str: The requirement of determinacy could also be put as follows: if a proposition is to have sense, the syntactic role of each of its parts must have been settled beforehand. For instance, it cannot occur to one only later on that a certain proposition follows from it. Before a proposition can have a sense, it must be completely settled what propositions follow from it.

sections.ger: Das Zeichen ist der sinnlich wahrnehmbare Teil des Symbols. Zwei verschiedene Symbole können also das Zeichen (Schriftzeichen oder Lautzeichen etc.) mit einander gemein haben — sie bezeichnen dann auf verschiedene Art und Weise.
sections.pmc: A sign is the part of a symbol that can be perceived. So one and the same sign (written or spoken etc.) can be common to two different symbols - in which case they will signify in different ways.
sections.str: A sign is the perceptible part of a symbol. Two different symbols can therefore have one and the same sign (written or spoken etc.)  in common - in which case each will signify in a different way.

sections.ger: 〟A" ist der selbe Buchstabe wie 〟A". Dies ist für unsere Sprache von großer Wichtigkeit.
sections.pmc: 'A' is the same letter as 'A'. This is of great importance for our language.
sections.str: “A” is the same letter as “A”. This is of great importance for our language.

sections.ger: Die Gesamtheit der wahren Sätze kann man auch die gesamte Naturwissenschaft nennen (oder die Gesamtheit der Naturwissenschaften).
sections.pmc: The totality of true propositions can also be called the whole of natural science (or the whole corpus of the natural sciences).
sections.str: The totality of true propositions can also be called the whole of natural science (or the totality of the natural sciences).pt

sections.ger:
Einen Satz verstehen heißt, wissen was der Fall ist, wenn er wahr ist.
Man kann ihn also verstehen ohne zu wissen ob er wahr ist.
sections.pmc:
To understand a proposition means to know what is the case if it is true.
One can understand it, therefore, without knowing whether it is true.
sections.str: To understand a proposition means to know what is the case if it is true.

sections.ger: Der Satz konstruiert eine Welt mit Hilfe seines logischen Gerüstes und darum kann man am Satz auch sehen, wie sich alles Logische verhielte, wenn er wahr wäre. Man kann aus einem falschen Satz Schlüsse ziehen.
sections.pmc: A proposition constructs a world with the help of its logical scaffolding, so that one can actually see from the proposition how everything would stand in logic, if it were true. One can draw inferences from a false proposition.
sections.str: A proposition constructs a world with the help of its logical scaffolding, so that one can actually see from the proposition all the logical features of reality, if it is true. One can draw inferences from a false proposition.

sections.ger: Jeder Satz muß schon Sinn haben; die Bejahung kann ihn ihm nicht geben, denn sie bejaht ja gerade den Sinn. Und dasselbe gilt von der Verneinung, etc.
sections.pmc: Every proposition must already have sense: it cannot be given sense by affirmation. Indeed its sense is just what is affirmed. And the same applies to negation.
sections.str: Every proposition must already have sense; assertion cannot give it a sense, for its sense is just what is asserted. And the same goes for negation, etc.

sections.ger: Man könnte sagen: die Verneinung bezieht sich schon auf den logischen Ort, den der verneinte Satz bestimmt. Der verneinende Satz bestimmt einen anderen logischen Ort als der verneinte.
sections.pmc:
One could say that negation must be related to the logical place determined by the negated proposition.
The negating proposition determines a logical place different from that of the negated proposition.
sections.str: One could say: the negation must be already related to the logical place determined by the negated proposition. The negating proposition determines a different logical place from the negated proposition.

sections.ger: Der verneinende Satz bestimmt seinen logischen Ort mit Hilfe des logischen Ortes des verneinten Satzes indem er jenen als außerhalb diesem liegend beschreibt.
sections.pmc: The negating proposition determines its logical place with the help of the logical place of the negated proposition. For it describes it as lying outside the latter's logical place.
sections.str: The negating proposition determines its logical place using the logical place of the negated proposition by describing it as lying outside the latter's logical place.

sections.ger: Daß man den verneinenden Satz wieder verneinen kann zeigt schon, daß das, was verneint wird, schon ein Satz, und nicht erst die Vorbereitung zu einem Satze ist.
sections.pmc: The negating proposition can be negated again, and this in itself shows that what is negated is already a proposition, and not merely something that is preliminary to a proposition.
sections.str: That the negated proposition can be negated again shows that what is negated is already a proposition, and not just something preliminary to a proposition.

sections.ger: Sind alle Sätze Wahrheitsfunktionen (W-Funktionen) von Elementarsätzen so folgt hieraus daß sie auch Wahrheitsfunktionen von einander sind.
sections.pmc: If all propositions are truth-functions (T-functions) of elementary propositions, it follows that they are also truth-functions of one another.
sections.str: If all propositions are truth-functions of elementary propositions, it follows that they are also truth-functions of one another.

sections.ger: Der Sinn einer Wahrheitsfunktion von p ist eine Funktion des Sinnes von p.
sections.pmc: The sense of a truth-function of p is a function of the sense of p.
sections.str: The sense of a truth-function of p is a function of the sense of p.

sections.ger: Jeder Satz folgt aus sich selbst.
sections.pmc: Every proposition follows from itself.

sections.ger: Folgt ein Satz aus anderen, so wird dies durch gewisse Beziehungen ausgedrückt, in welchen die Formen jener Sätze zu einander stehen; und zwar brauchen wir sie nicht erst in diese Beziehung zu setzen, indem wir sie in einem Satz mit einander verbinden, sondern diese Beziehungen sind intern und bestehen, sobald, und dadurch daß, jene Satzzeichen bestehen.
sections.pmc: If one proposition follows from others, this is expressed by certain relations in which the forms of the propositions stand to one another: nor is it necessary for us to set up this relation between them, by combining them with one another in a single proposition; on the contrary, the relations are internal, and their existence is an immediate result of the existence of the propositional signs.
sections.str: If one proposition follows from others, this is expressed by certain relations in which the forms of those propositions stand to one another: nor need we to set up this relation between them, by combining them with one another in a single proposition. On the contrary, the relations are internal, and  exist simultaneously with, and through, the existence of the sentential signs.

sections.ger: 〟Schlußgesetze" welche — wie bei Frege und Russell — die Schlüsse rechtfertigen sollen sind sinnlos, und wären überflüssig.
sections.pmc: 'Laws of inference', which are supposed to justify inferences, as in the works of Frege and Russell, have no sense, and would be superfluous.
sections.str: “Laws of inference”, which—as in Frege and Russell—are supposed to justify inferences, are senseless and would be superfluous.

sections.ger: Ein Satz kann zwar ein unvollständiges Bild einer gewissen Sachlage sein, aber er ist immer ein vollständiges Bild.
sections.pmc: A proposition may well be an incomplete picture of a certain situation, but it is always a complete picture of something.
sections.str: A proposition may well be an incomplete picture of a certain situation, but it is always a complete picture.

sections.ger: Die logischen Sätze beschreiben das Gerüste der Welt, oder vielmehr, sie stellen es dar. Sie 〟handeln" von nichts. Sie setzen voraus, daß Namen Bedeutung, und Elementarsätze Sinn haben: und dies ist ihre Verbindung mit der Welt. Es ist klar, daß es etwas über die Welt anzeigen muß, daß gewisse Verbindungen von Symbolen — welche notwendigerweise einen bestimmten Charakter haben — Tautologien sind. Hierin liegt das Entscheidende. Wir sagten, manches an den Zeichen die wir gebrauchen wäre willkürlich, manches nicht. In der Logik drückt nur dieses aus: das heißt aber, in der Logik drücken nicht wir mit Hilfe der Zeichen aus, was wir wollen, sondern in der Logik sagt die Natur dernaturnotwendigen Zeichen selbst aus: Wenn wir die logische Syntax irgend einer Zeichensprache kennen, dann sind bereits alle logischen Sätze gegeben.
sections.pmc: The propositions of logic describe the scaffolding of the world, or rather they represent it. They have no 'subject-matter'. They presuppose that names have meaning and elementary propositions have sense; and that is their connection with the world. It is clear that something about the world must be indicated by the fact that certain combinations of symbols - which necessarily have a determinate character - are tautologies. This contains the decisive point. We have said that some things are arbitary in the signs that we use and that some things are not. In logic it is only the latter that express: but that means that logic is not a field in which we express what we wish with the help of signs, but rather one in which the nature of the natural and inevitable signs speaks for itself. If we know the logical syntax of any sign-language, then we have already been given all the logical propositions.
sections.str: The logical propositions describe the scaffolding of the world, or rather, they represent it. They are not “about” anything. They presuppose that names  mean something and elementary propositions make sense: and this is their connection with the world. Clearly, that certain combinations of symbols, symbols with a necessarily determinate character, are tautologies indicates something about the world. That’s the decisive point. We have said that in the signs we use, some things are arbitary, some things are not. In logic it is only the latter that express: but that means that in logic it is not we who express what we want by means of of signs, but rather in logic the nature of the inevitably necessary signs speaks for itself. If we know the logical syntax of any sign language, then all the logical propositions are already given.

sections.ger: Es ist möglich, und zwar auch nach der alten Logik, von vornherein eine Beschreibung aller 〟wahren" logischen Sätze zu geben.
sections.pmc: It is possible - indeed possible even in the old logic - to give in advance a description of all 'true' logical propositions.
sections.str: It is possible - indeed possible even in the old logic - to give from the start a description of all “true” logical propositions.

sections.ger: Darum kann es in der Logik auch nie Überraschungen geben.
sections.pmc: Hence there can never be suprises in logic.
sections.str: Hence there can never be suprises in logic.

sections.ger: Ob ein Satz der Logik angehört kann man berechnen, indem man die logischen Eigenschaften des Symbols berechnet.
sections.pmc: One can calculate whether a proposition belongs to logic, by calculating the logical properties of the symbol.
sections.str: By calculating the logical properties of the symbol, one can calculate whether a proposition belongs to logic.

sections.ger: Und dies tun wir wenn wir einen logischen Satz 〟beweisen". Denn ohne uns um einen Sinn oder Bedeutung zu kümmern bilden wir den logischen Satz aus anderen nach bloßen Zeichenregeln.
sections.pmc: And this is what we do when we 'prove' a logical proposition. For, without bothering about sense or meaning, we construct the logical proposition out of others using only rules that deal with signs.
sections.str: And that’s what we do when we “prove” a logical proposition. For, without bothering about sense or meaning, we construct the logical proposition out of others using only rules for signs.

sections.ger:
Alle Sätze der Logik sind gleichberechtigt es gibt unter ihnen nicht wesentlich Grundgesetze und abgeleitete Sätze.
Jede Tautologie zeigt selbst daß sie eine Tautologie ist.
sections.pmc:
All the propositions of logic are of equal status: it is not the case that some of them are essentially primitive propositions and others essentially derived propositions.
Every tautology itself shows that it is a tautology.
sections.str: All propositions in logic are of equal rank, rather than some being essentially primitive propositions from which others are derived. Every tautology itself shows that it is a tautology.

sections.ger: Immer kann man aber die Logik so auffassen daß jeder Satz sein eigener Beweis ist.
sections.pmc: However it is always possible to construe logic in such a way that every proposition is its own proof.
sections.str: However, logic can always be conceived in such a way that every proposition is its own proof.

sections.ger: Das sogenannte Gesetz der Induktion kann jedenfalls kein logisches Gesetz sein, denn es ist offenbar ein sinnvoller Satz. — Und darum kann es auch kein Gesetz a priori sein.
sections.pmc: The so-called law of induction cannot possibly be a law of logic, since it is obviously a proposition with sense. Nor, therefore, can it be an a priori law.
sections.str: The so-called law of induction cannot possibly be a law of logic, for obviously it is a meaningful proposition. And so it cannot be an a priori law either.

sections.ger: Was das Bild darstellt, ist sein Sinn.
sections.pmc: What a picture represents is its sense.
sections.str: What a picture represents is its sense.

sections.ger: Nach dieser Auffassung gehört also zum Bild auch noch die abbildende Beziehung die es zum Bild macht.
sections.pmc: So a picture, conceived in this way, also includes the pictorial relationship, which makes it into a picture.
sections.str: A picture, conceived in this way, also includes the pictorial relationship which makes the picture a picture.

sections.ger: Das Bild stellt sein Objekt von außerhalb dar, (sein Standpunkt ist seine Form der Darstellung) darum stellt das Bild sein Objekt richtig oder falsch dar.
sections.pmc: A picture represents its subject from a position outside it. (Its standpoint is its representational form.) That is why a picture represents its subject correctly or incorrectly.
sections.str: A picture represents its subject from the outside. (Its point of view is its form of representation.) That is how it represents its subject correctly or incorrectly.

sections.ger: Der Satz, welcher vom Komplex handelt steht in interner Beziehung zum Satze, der von dessen Bestandteil handelt.
sections.pmc: A proposition about a complex stands in an internal relation to a proposition about a constituent of the complex.
sections.str: A proposition about a complex stands in an internal relation to a proposition about a constituent part.

sections.ger: In der Umgangssprache kommt es ungemein häufig vor daß dasselbe Wort auf verschiedene Art und Weise bezeichnen — also verschiedenen Symbolen angehören — kann oder doch daß zwei Wörter die auf verschiedene Art und Weise bezeichnen äußerlich auf gleiche Art und Weise im Satze angewendet werden.
sections.pmc: Now in everyday language it very frequently happens that the same word can have different modes of signification - and so belong to different symbols; or that two words that have different modes of signification are employed in propositions in what is superficially the same way.
sections.str: Now in ordinary language it very often happens that the same word signifies in different ways - and so belongs to different symbols - or that two words that signify in different ways are applied in sentences in what looks like the same way.

sections.ger: So erscheint das Wort 〟ist" als Kopula, als Gleichheitszeichen und als Ausdruck der Existenz; das Wort 〟Grün" als Eigenschaftswort und als Personenname; 〟Identisch" wird wie ein Eigenschaftswort angewandt etc. etc.. Im Satze 〟Grün ist Grün" (wo 〟ist" die Kopula bedeutet) haben das erste und das letzte Wort nicht einfach verschiedene Bedeutung sondern es sind verschiedene Symbole.
sections.pmc: Thus the word 'is' figures as the copula, as a sign for identity, and as an expression for existence; the word 'Green' figures as an adjective and as the proper name of a person; 'identical' is employed as an adjective, etc. etc. In the proposition 'Green is green' (when 'is' means the copula) the first word and the last do not merely have different meanings; they are different symbols.
sections.str: Thus the word “is” appears as a copula, as a sign for identity, and as an expression for existence; the word “Green” figures as an adjective and as the proper name of a person; “identical” is employed as an adjective, etc. etc. In the proposition “Green is green” (when “is” means the copula) not only do the first word and the last have different meanings, they are different symbols.

sections.ger: So entstehen leicht die fundamentalsten Verwechslungen (deren die ganze Philosophie voll ist).
sections.pmc: In this way the most fundamental confusions are easily produced (the whole of philosophy is full of them).
sections.str: This is how the most fundamental confusions easily arise (all philosophy is full of them).

sections.ger: Die Philosophie ist keine der Naturwissenschaften.
sections.pmc: Philosophy is not one of the natural sciences.
sections.str: Philosophy is not one of the natural sciences.

sections.ger: Man versteht ihn, wenn man seine Bestandteile versteht.
sections.pmc: It is understood by anyone who understands its constituents.
sections.str: One understands it if one understands its constituents.

sections.ger: Wohlgemerkt: Die Übersetzung einer Sprache in eine andere geht nicht so vor sich, daß man jeden Satz der einen in einen der anderen übersetzt, sondern nur die Satzbestandteile werden übersetzt.
sections.pmc: Note that when translating one language into another, we do not proceed by translating each proposition of the one into one belonging to the other, but merely by translating the constituents of propositions.
sections.str: Note that translating one language into another is not a matter of translating each proposition of the one into one of the other: rather, it is only the constituents that are translated.

sections.ger: Und das Wörterbuch übersetzt nicht nur Substantiva sondern auch Zeit- und Eigenschafts- Bindeworte etc.; und es behandelt sie alle gleich.
sections.pmc: And the dictionary translates not only substantives, but also verbs, adjectives, and conjunctions, etc.; and it treats them all in the same way.
sections.str: And the dictionary translates not only substantives, but also verbs, adjectives, and conjunctions, etc.; and it treats them all alike.

sections.ger: Die Schemata haben auch dann eine Bedeutung, wenn 〟p" 〟q" 〟r" etc. nicht Elementarsätze sind.
sections.pmc: The schemata in 4.31 have a meaning even when 'p', 'q', 'r', etc. are not elementary propositions.
sections.str: The schemas in 4.31 are meaningful even when “p”, “q”, “r”, etc. are not elementary propositions.

sections.ger: Und es ist leicht zu sehen, daß das Satzzeichen erster Art, auch wenn p, q etc. W-Funktionen von Elementarsätzen sind, eine W-Funktion von Elementarsätzen ausdrückt.
sections.pmc: And it is easy to see that a propositional sign of the first kind expresses a single T-function of elementary propositions even when p, q, etc. are T-functions of elementary propositions.
sections.str: And it is easy to see that a sentential sign of the first kind expresses a single truth-function of elementary propositions even when “p”, “q”, etc. are truth-functions of elementary propositions.

sections.ger: Aus einem Elementarsatz läßt sich kein anderer folgern.
sections.pmc: One elementary proposition cannot be deduced from another.
sections.str: From an elementary proposition, no other can be deduced.

sections.ger: Wenn wir von p ∨ q und ~p auf q schließen, so ist hier durch die Bezeichnungsweise die Beziehung der Satzformen von 〟p ∨ q" und 〟~p" verhüllt. Schreiben wir aber statt 〟p ∨ q" 〟p|q ·|· p|q" und statt 〟~p" 〟p|p" (p|q = weder p noch q) so wird der innere Zusammenhang offenbar.
sections.pmc: When we infer q from p∨q and ~p, the relation between the propositional forms of 'p∨q' and '~p' is masked, in this ase, by our mode of signifying. But if instead of 'p∨q' we write 'p|q.|.p|q', and instead of '~p', 'p|p' (p|q = neither p nor q), then the inner connection becomes obvious.
sections.str: When from p ∨q and ~p we infer q, the relation between the propositional forms of “p ∨q” and “~p” is concealed, by our mode of signifying. But if instead of “p ∨q” we write “p |q.|.p|q”, and instead of “~p”, “p|p” (p|q = neither p nor q), then the inner connection becomes obvious.

sections.ger: Der Beweis der logischen Sätze besteht darin, daß wir sie aus anderen logischen Sätzen durch sukzessive Anwendung gewisser Operationen entstehen lassen die aus den ersten immer wieder Tautologien macht. (Und zwar folgen aus einer Tautologie nur Tautologien.)
sections.pmc: The proof of logical propositions consists in the following process: we produce them out of other logical propositions by successively applying certain operations that always make further tautologies out of the initial ones. (And in fact only tautologies follow from a tautology.)
sections.str: Here is how we prove a logical proposition: we generate it from other logical propositions by successively applying certain operations that always produce further tautologies from the first. (And only tautologies follow from a tautology.)

sections.ger:
Es ist klar daß die Anzahl der 〟logischen Grundgesetze" willkürlich ist denn man könnte die Logik ja aus einemGrundgesetz ableiten indem man einfach z.B. aus Freges Grundgesetzen das logische Produkt bildet. 
(Frege hätte vielleicht gesagt daß dieses Grundgesetz nun nicht mehr unmittelbar einleuchte. Aber es ist merkwürdig daß ein so exakter Denker wie Frege sich auf den Grad des Einleuchtens als Kriterium des logischen Satzes berufen hat.)
sections.pmc:
It is clear that the number of the 'primitive propositions of logic' is arbitrary, since one could derive logic from a single primitive proposition, e.g. by simply constructing the logical product of Frege's primitive propositions.
(Frege would perhaps have said that we should then no longer have an immediately self-evident primitive proposition. But it is remarkable that a thinker as rigorous as Frege appealed to the degree of self-evidence as the criterion of a logical proposition.)
sections.str: It is clear that the number of “basic laws of logic” is arbitrary, since we could derive logic from a single primitive proposition simply by constructing, for example, the logical product of Frege's basic laws.(Frege might say that this basic law would no longer be immediately self-evident. But what is amazing is that a thinker as precise as Frege appealed to the degree of self-evidence as a criterion of a logical proposition.)

sections.ger: Der Beweis in der Logik ist nur ein mechanisches Hilfsmittel zum leichteren Erkennen der Tautologie wo sie kompliziert ist.
sections.pmc: Proof in logic is merely a mechanical expedient to facilitate the recognition of tautologies in complicated cases.
sections.str: Proof in logic is merely a mechanical expedient enabling the recognition of a tautology in complicated cases.

sections.ger: Im Leben ist es ja nie der logische Satz, den wir brauchen, sondern wir benützen den logischen Satz nur um aus Sätzen welche nicht der Logik angehören auf andere zu schließen die gleichfalls nicht der Logik angehören.
sections.pmc: Indeed in real life a logical proposition is never what we want. Rather, we make use of logical propositions only in inferences from propositions that do not belong to logic to others that likewise do not belong to logic.
sections.str: Indeed in everyday life we never need logical propositions. Rather, we make se of logical propositions only to infer from propositions that are not part of logic to others that also are not logical.

sections.ger: In der Philosophie führt die Frage 〟wozu gebrauchen wir eigentlich jenes Wort, jenen Satz" immer wieder zu wertvollen Einsichten.
sections.pmc: In philosophy the question, 'What do we actually use this word or this proposition for?' repeatedly leads to valuable insights.
sections.str: In philosophy the question, “How do we actually use this word or this proposition?” repeatedly leads to valuable insights.

sections.ger: In seiner Übereinstimmung oder nicht Übereinstimmung seines Sinnes mit der Wirklichkeit besteht seine Wahrheit oder Falschheit.
sections.pmc: The agreement and disagreement of its sense with reality constitutes its truth or falsity.
sections.str: The agreement and disagreement of its sense with reality constitutes its truth or falsehood.

sections.ger: Die abbildende Beziehung besteht aus den Zuordnungen der Elemente des Bildes und der Sachen.
sections.pmc: The pictorial relationship consists of the correlation of the picture's elements with things.
sections.str: The pictorial relationship consists of the correlation of the picture's elements with things.

sections.ger: Das Bild kann sich aber nicht außerhalb seiner Form der Darstellung stellen.
sections.pmc: A picture cannot, however, place itself outside its representational form.
sections.str: A picture cannot, however, place itself outside its form of representation.

sections.ger: Der Komplex kann nur durch seine Beschreibung gegeben sein, und diese wird stimmen oder nicht stimmen. Der Satz in welchem von einem Komplex die Rede ist, wird, wenn dieser nicht existiert, nicht unsinnig sondern einfach falsch sein.
sections.pmc: A complex can be given only by its description, which will be right or wrong. A proposition that mentions a complex will not be nonsensical, if the complex does not exist, but simply false.
sections.str: A complex can be given only by its description, which either will fit or not fit. A proposition that mentions a complex that does not exist will not be nonsensical, merely false.

sections.ger: Wir reden von etwas, aber auch davon, daß etwas geschieht.
sections.pmc: We speak of something but also of something's happening.
sections.str: We speak of something but also of something's happening.

sections.ger: Das Wort 〟Philosophie" muß etwas bedeuten, das über oder unter, aber nicht neben den Naturwissenschaften steht.
sections.pmc: The word 'philosophy' must mean something whose place is above or below the natural sciences, not beside them.
sections.str: The word “philosophy” must mean something that stands above or below the natural sciences, not alongside them.

sections.ger: Daß man aus (x)·ϕx auf ϕa schließen kann, das zeigt, wie die Allgemeinheit auch im Zeichen 〟(x)·ϕx" vorhanden ist.
sections.pmc: The possibility of inference from (x).ϕx to ϕa shows how the symbol '(x).ϕx' itself has generality in it.
sections.str: That we can infer from (x).ϕx to ϕa shows that the symbol “(x).ϕx” itself  already has generality in it.

sections.ger: Das Anzeichen des logischen Satzes ist nicht die Allgemeingültigkeit. Allgemein sein heißt ja nur: zufälligerweise für alle Dinge gelten.
sections.pmc:
The mark of a logical proposition is not general validity.
To be general means no more than to be accidentally valid for all things.
sections.str: General validity is not the mark of logical propositions. To be general only means to be accidentally valid for all things.

sections.ger: Ein unverallgemeinerter Satz kann ja ebensowohl tautologisch sein als ein verallgemeinerter.
sections.pmc: An ungeneralized proposition can be tautological just as well as a generalized one.
sections.str: An ungeneralized proposition can be a tautology just as well as a generalized one.

sections.ger: Die logische Allgemeingültigkeit könnte man wesentlich nennen, im Gegensatz zu jener zufälligen, etwa des Satzes 〟alle Menschen sind sterblich". Sätze wie Russells Axiom of reducibility sind nicht logische Sätze, und dies erklärt unser Gefühl , nämlich, daß sie, wenn wahr, so doch nur durch einen günstigen Zufall wahr sein könnten.
sections.pmc: The general validity of logic might be called essential, in contrast with the accidental general validity of such propositions as 'All men are mortal'. Propositions like Russell's axiom of reducibility are not logical propositons, and this explains our feeling that, even if they were true, their truth could only be the result of a fortunate accident.
sections.str: We could call the general validity of logic essential, as opposed to the accidental general validity of such propositions as “All people are mortal”. Propositions like Russell's axiom of reducibility are not logical propositions, and this explains our feeling that, if true, that could only be a lucky fluke.

sections.ger: Es läßt sich eine Welt denken, in der das Axiom of reducibility nicht gilt. Es ist aber klar daß die Logik nichts mit der Frage zu schaffen hat ob unsere Welt wirklich so ist oder nicht.
sections.pmc: It is possible to imagine a world in which the axiom of reducibility is not valid. It is clear, however, that logic has nothing to do with the question whether our world really is like that or not.
sections.str: We can imagine a world in which the axiom of reducibility is not valid. But clearly, logic has nothing to do with the question whether our world is really like that or not.

sections.ger: Natürlich ist diese Art, zu zeigen, daß Sätze Tautologien sind der Logik durchaus unwesentlich. Schon weil die Sätze von welchen der Beweis ausgeht ja ohne Beweis zeigen müssen daß sie Tautologien sind.
sections.pmc: Of course this way of showing that propositions are tautologies is not at all essential to logic, if only because the propositions from which the proof starts must show without any proof that they are tautologies.
sections.str: Naturally this way of showing that propositions are tautologies is quite inessential to logic. For the propositions from which the proof starts must show without any proof that they are tautologies.

sections.ger: Es wäre ja auch zu merkwürdig wenn man einen sinnvollen Satz logisch aus anderen beweisen könnte und einen logischen Satz auch. Es ist von vornherein klar daß der logische Beweis eines sinnvollen Satzes und der Beweis in der Logik zwei ganz verschiedene Sachen sein müssen.
sections.pmc: Indeed, it would be altogether remarkable if a proposition that had sense could be proved logically from others, and so too could a logical proposition. It is clear from the start that a logical proof of a proposition that has sense and a proof in logic must be two entirely different things.
sections.str: Indeed, it would be quite incredible if a meaningful proposition could be proved logically from others just as a logical proposition can. Clearly, proving logically that a meaningful proposition is true is completely different from a proof in logic.

sections.ger: Um zu erkennen, ob das Bild wahr oder falsch ist, müssen wir es mit der Wirklichkeit vergleichen.
sections.pmc: In order to tell whether a picture is true or false we must compare it with reality.
sections.str: To see whether a picture is true or false we must compare it with reality.

sections.ger: Diese Zuordnungen sind gleichsam die Fühler der Bildelemente, mit denen das Bild die Wirklichkeit berührt.
sections.pmc: These correlations are, as it were, the feelers of the picture's elements, with which the picture touches reality.
sections.str: These correlations are, as it were, the antennae of the picture's elements, which put the picture in touch with reality.

sections.ger: Daß ein einfaches Symbol einen Komplex bezeichnet, kann man aus einer Unbestimmtheit in den Sätzen sehen, worin es vorkommt. Wir wissen, durch diesen Satz ist noch nicht alles bestimmt. Die Allgemeinheitsbezeichnung enthält ja ein Urbild.
sections.pmc: When a simple symbol signifies a complex, this can be seen from an indeterminateness in the propositions in which it occurs. In such cases we know that the proposition leaves something undetermined. In fact the generality-sign contains a prototype.
sections.str: When a simple symbol signifies a complex, this can be seen in an indeterminateness in the propositions in which it occurs. We then know that everything is not yet determined by the proposition. Indeed, the generality sign contains a prototype.

sections.ger:
Die stillschweigenden Abmachungen zum Verständnis unserer Sprache sind enorm kompliziert zu jedem Satz wird viel hinzu gedacht, was nicht ausgesprochen wird. 
Ist mit 〟A" ein Mensch gemeint so ist der Satz 〟A sitzt" zulässig, aber nicht wenn A dieses Buch bezeichnet. — Ist aber ein Satz ganz zerlegt dann müssen für alles was vom Verständnis seiner Form abhängt die Bedeutungen seiner Teile belanglos sein.
sections.pmc:
The tacit conventions on which the understanding of our language depends are enormously complicated. With every proposition much is supplied in thought which is not put into words.
If 'A' is used to mean a person, the proposition, 'A is sitting', is admissible, but not if 'A' signifies this book. - But once a proposition is completely analyzed, everything that depends upon the understanding of its form must be unaffected by the meanings of its parts.
sections.str: The unspoken conventions involved in understanding our language are extremely complicated. Much is added in thought to each proposition and not put into words.If “A” is used to mean a person, the proposition, “A is sitting”, is admissible, but not if “A” signifies this book. - But if a proposition is fully analyzed, everything that depends upon the understanding of its form must be unaffected by the meanings of its parts.

sections.ger: Der Zweck der Philosophie ist die logische Klärung der Gedanken.
sections.pmc: Philosophy aims at the logical clarification of thoughts.
sections.str: The goal of philosophy is the logical clarification of thoughts.

sections.ger: Auf keine Weise kann aus dem Bestehen irgend einer Sachlage, auf das Bestehen einer von ihr gänzlich verschiedenen Sachlage geschlossen werden.
sections.pmc: There is no possible way of making an inference from the existence of one situation to the existence of another, entirely different situation.
sections.str: In no way can an inference be made from the existence of one situation to the existence of another entirely different situation.

sections.ger: Einen Kausalnexus der einen solchen Schluß rechtfertigte gibt es nicht.
sections.pmc: There is no causal nexus to justify such an inference.
sections.str: There is no causal nexus to justify any such inference.

sections.ger: Die Ereignisse der Zukunft können wir nicht wissen.
sections.pmc: The events of the future cannot be known.
sections.str: Future events cannot be known.

sections.ger: Der Glaube an den Kausalnexus ist der Aberglaube.
sections.pmc: Belief in the causal nexus is superstition.
sections.str: Superstition is belief in the causal nexus.

sections.ger: Die Willensfreiheit besteht darin, daß zukünftige Ereignisse jetzt nicht gewußt werden können. Nur dann könnten wir sie wissen, wenn die Kausalität eine innere Notwendigkeit wäre, wie die, des logischen Schlusses. — Der Zusammenhang von Wissen und Gewußtem ist der, der logischen Notwendigkeit.
sections.pmc: The freedom of the will consists in the impossibility of knowing events that still lie in the future. We could know them only if causality were an inner necessity like that of logical inference. - The connection between knowledge and what is known is that of logical necessity.
