sections.pmc: It has to be possible to answer a priori the question whether I can get into a position in which I need a 27-termed relation in order to signify something.
sections.str: It has to be possible to answer a priori the question whether I can get into a position in which I need a 27-termed relation to signify something.

sections.ger: Dürfen wir denn aber überhaupt so fragen? Können wir eine Zeichenform aufstellen und nicht wissen ob ihr etwas entsprechen könne?
sections.pmc: But is it really legitimate even to ask such a question? Can we set up a form of sign without knowing whether anything can correspond to it.
sections.str: But can it even be legitimate to ask such a question? How can we set up a form of a sign without knowing whether anything can correspond to it?

sections.ger: Hat die Frage einen Sinn: Was muß sein damit etwas der Fall — sein kann?
sections.pmc: Does it make sense to ask what there must be in order that something can be the case?
sections.str: Does it make sense to ask what there must be such that something can be the case?

sections.ger: Wo immer man Zeichen nach einem System bilden kann, dort ist das System das logisch Wichtige und nicht die einzelnen Zeichen.
sections.pmc: But when there is a system by which we can create signs, the system is important for logic and not the individual signs.
sections.str: But when we have a system for creating signs, the system is what is important for logic and not the individual signs.

sections.ger:
Es verändert ja die Wahr- oder Falschheit jedes Satzes etwas am allgemeinen Bau der Welt. Und der Spielraum welcher ihrem Bau durch die Gesamtheit der Elementarsätze gelassen wird, ist eben derjenige, welchen die ganz allgemeinen Sätze begrenzen. 
(Denn wenn ein Elementarsatz wahr ist, so ist damit doch jedenfalls ein Elementarsatz mehr wahr.)
sections.pmc:
The truth or falsity of every proposition does make some alteration in the general construction of the world. And the range that the totality of elementary propositions leaves open for its construction is exactly the same as that which is delimited by entirely general propositions.
(For if an elementary proposition is true, that means, at any rate, one more true elementary proposition.)
sections.str: The truth or falsity of every proposition alters something about the general structure of the world. And the play that is left open to it structure by the totality of elementary propositions leaves open for its construction is precisely what is delimited by the entirely general propositions. (For if an elementary proposition is true, then, at any rate, one more elementary proposition is true.)

sections.ger: Das was das Axiom of infinity sagen soll würde sich in der Sprache dadurch ausdrücken daß es unendlich viele Namen mit verschiedener Bedeutung gäbe.
sections.pmc: What the axiom of infinity is intended to say would express itself in language through the existence of infinitely many names with different meanings.
sections.str: What the axiom of infinity is supposed to say would be expressed in language by there being infinitely many names with different meanings.

sections.ger: Der Ausdruck der Übereinstimmung und nicht Übereinstimmung mit den Wahrheitsmöglichkeiten der Elementarsätze drückt die Wahrheitsbedingungen des Satzes aus.
sections.pmc: The expression of agreement and disagreement with the truth-possibilities of elementary propositions expresses the truth-conditions of a proposition.
sections.str: The expression of agreement and disagreement with the truth-possibilities of elementary propositions expresses the truth-conditions of a proposition.

sections.ger: Hiernach scheint es nun möglich zu sein die allgemeinste Satzform anzugeben; d.h. eine Beschreibung der Satzzeichenirgend einer Zeichensprache zu geben, so daß jeder mögliche Sinn durch ein Zeichen auf welches die Beschreibung paßt ausgedrückt werden kann, und daß jedes Zeichen worauf die Beschreibung paßt einen Sinn ausdrücken kann, wenn die Bedeutung der einfachen Zeichen entsprechend gewählt wird.
sections.pmc: Accordingly it now seems possible to give the most general propositional form: that is, to give a description of the propositional signs of any sign-language whatsoever in such a way that every possible sense can be expressed by a sign satisfying the description, and every sign satisfying the description can express a sense, provided that the meanings of the simple signs are suitably chosen.
sections.str: Accordingly it now seems possible to give the most general propositional form: that is, to describe the sentential signs of any sign-language whatsoever so that every possible sense can be expressed by a sign that falls under the description, and every sign that falls under the description can express a sense, provided that the meanings of the simple signs are suitably chosen.

sections.ger: Es ist klar, daß bei der Beschreibung der allgemeinsten Satzform nur ihr Wesentliches beschrieben werden darf, — sonst wäre sie nämlich nicht die allgemeinste.
sections.pmc: It is clear that only what is essential to the most general propositional form may be included in its description - for otherwise it would not be the most general form.
sections.str: Clearly, only what is essential to the most general propositional form may be included in its description -  otherwise, it would not be the most general form.

sections.ger: Daß es eine allgemeine Satzform gibt, wird dadurch bewiesen, daß es keinen Satz geben darf dessen Form man nicht hätte voraussehen (d.h. konstruieren) können.
sections.pmc: The existence of a general propositional form is proved by the fact that there cannot be a proposition whose form could not have been forseen (i.e. constructed).
sections.str: That no proposition can be given whose form could not have been forseen (i.e. constructed) proves the existence of a general propositional form.

sections.ger: Angenommen uns wären alle einfachen Sätze gegeben. Dann läßt sich einfach fragen, welche Sätze kann ich aus ihnen bilden. Und das sind alle Sätze und so sind sie begrenzt.
sections.pmc: Suppose that we are given all simple propositions, then we can simply ask: what propositions can I construct out of these? And there we have all propositions and that fixes their limits.
sections.str: Suppose we were given all simple propositions. Then we can simply ask what propositions I can construct out of them. And these are all the propositions and that is how they are limited.

sections.ger: Die Sätze sind alles was aus der Gesamtheit aller Elementarsätze folgt. (Natürlich auch daraus daß es die Gesamtheit aller ist.)
sections.pmc: Propositions comprise all that follows from the totality of all elementary propositions (and, of course, from its being the totality of them all).
sections.str: Propositions are all that follows from the totality of all elementary propositions (and, of course, from its being the totality of them all.)

sections.ger:
Also ist z.B. ’
' p | q | '
W | F | W
W |W | W
F | F |
F | W | W
ein Satzzeichen.
sections.pmc:
So for example, the following is a propositional sign.
' p| q | '
T | F | T
T | T | T
F | F |
F | T | T
sections.str: So for example, thisis a sentential sign.

sections.ger: Freges Zeichen 〟✓" ist logisch ganz bedeutungslos es zeigt bei Frege (und Russell) nur an daß diese Autoren die so bezeichneten Sätze für wahr halten. 〟✓" gehört daher ebensowenig zum Satzgefüge wie etwa die Nummer des Satzes. Ein Satz kann unmöglich von sich selbst aussagen daß er wahr ist.
sections.pmc: Frege's sign '⊢' is logically quite meaningless: in the works of Frege (and Russell) it simply indicates that these authors hold the propositions marked with this sign to be true. Thus '⊢' is no more a component part of a proposition than is, for instance, the proposition's number. It is quite impossible for a proposition to state that it itself is true.
sections.str: Frege's sign “⊢” is logically quite meaningless: in Frege (and Russell) it only indicates that these authors hold the sentences marked in this way to be true. Thus “⊢” is no more a component part of a proposition than is, for instance, the proposition's number. A proposition cannot possibly assert of itself that is true.

sections.ger: Schreiben wir diese Kolonne als Reihe hin so wird das Zeichen in 〟(WWFW) (p,q)" oder 〟(W,W, ,W) (p,q)".
sections.pmc: If we now write this column as a row, the sign in 4.432 will become '(TTFT)(p, q)' or (T, T,  , T)(p, q)'.
sections.str: If we now write this column as a row, the sign in 4.432 will become “(TTFT )(p, q)” or “(T, T,  , T)(p, q)”.

sections.ger: Eine ausgezeichnete Zahl gibt es nicht.
sections.pmc: There is no privileged number.
sections.str: There is no privileged number.

sections.ger: Die Logik erfüllt die Welt; die Grenzen der Welt sind auch ihre Grenzen.
sections.pmc: Logic pervades the world: the limits of the world are also its limits.
sections.str: Logic permeates the world: the limits of the world are also its limits.

sections.ger: Und wie wäre es auch möglich daß ich es in der Logik mit Formen zu tun hätte, die ich erfinden kann, sondern mit dem muß ich es zu tun haben, was es mir möglich macht sie zu erfinden.
sections.pmc: And anyway, is it really possible that in logic I should have to deal with forms I can invent? What I have to deal with must be that which makes it possible for me to invent them.
sections.str: And in any case, how could logic demand that I must deal with forms that I can invent?  I must, rather, deal with that which makes it possible for me to invent forms.

sections.ger: Die Grenzen meiner Sprache bedeuten die Grenzen meiner Welt.
sections.pmc: The limits of my language mean the limits of my world.
sections.str: The limits of my language mean the limits of my world.

sections.ger: Diese Bemerkung gibt den Schlüssel zur Entscheidung, inwieweit der Solipsismus eine Wahrheit ist.
sections.pmc: This remark provides the key to the problem how much truth there is in solipsism.
sections.str: This remark provides the key to the problem how much truth there is in solipsism.

sections.ger: Was der Solipsismus nämlich meint ist ganz richtig nur läßt es sich nicht sagen, sondern es zeigt sich.
sections.pmc: For what the solipsist means is quite correct; only it cannot be said, but makes itself manifest.
sections.str: Namely: what solipsism means is quite correct, only it cannot be said, but shows itself.

sections.ger: Daß die Welt meine Welt ist das zeigt sich darin daß die Grenzen der Sprache (der Sprache die allein ich verstehe) die Grenzen meiner Welt bedeuten.
sections.pmc: The world is my world: this is manifest in the fact that the limits of language (of that language which alone I understand) mean the limits of my world.
sections.str: That the world is my world shows itself in the fact that the limits of language (the only language I understand) mean the limits of my world.

sections.ger: Das denkende, vorstellende Subjekt gibt es nicht.
sections.pmc: There is no such thing as the subject that thinks or entertains ideas.
sections.str: The subject that thinks, entertains ideas: there is no such thing.

sections.ger:
Hier sieht man daß der Solipsismus streng durchgeführt mit dem reinen Realismus zusammenfällt. 
Das Ich des Solipsismus schrumpft zum ausdehnungslosen Punkt zusammen und es bleibt die ihm koordinierte Realität.
sections.pmc: Here it can be seen that solipsism, when its implications are followed out strictly, coincides with pure realism. The self of solipsism shrinks to a point without extension, and there remains the reality co-ordinate with it.
sections.str: Here one sees that solipsism, strictly worked out, coincides with pure realism. The I of solipsism shrinks to an extensionless point, and what remains is the reality co-ordinated with it.

sections.ger: Der Satz ist der Ausdruck seiner Wahrheitsbedingungen.
sections.pmc: A proposition is the expression of its truth conditions.
sections.str: A proposition is the expression of its truth conditions.

sections.ger: Frege hat sie daher ganz richtig als Erklärung der Zeichen seiner Begriffsschrift vorausgeschickt. Nur ist die Erklärung des Wahrheitsbegriffes bei Frege falsch: Wären 〟das Wahre" und 〟das Falsche" wirklich Gegenstände und die Argumente in ~p etc. dann wäre nach Freges 〟Bestimmung" der Sinn von ~p keineswegs bestimmt.
sections.pmc: Thus Frege was quite right to use them as a starting point when he explained the signs of his conceptual notation. But the explanation of the concept of truth that Frege gives is mistaken: if 'the true' and 'the false' were really objects, and were the arguments in ~p, etc., then Frege's method of 'determining' the sense of ~p would leave it absolutely undetermined.
sections.str: So Frege was quite right to start with them in explaining the signs of his conceptual notation. But Frege’s explanation of the concept of truth is wrong: if “the true” and “the false” were real objects, and were the arguments in ~p, etc., then the sense of ~p would not in the least be determined by Frege's  “determination.”

sections.ger: Die allgemeine Satzform ist eine Variable.
sections.pmc: The general propositional form is the variable.
sections.str: The general propositional form is a variable.

sections.ger: So könnte man in gewissem Sinne sagen daß alle Sätze Verallgemeinerungen aus den Elementarsätzen sind.
sections.pmc: Thus, in a certain sense, it could be said that all propositions were generalizations from elementary propositions.
sections.str: So one could say, in a certain sense, that all propositions are generalizations of elementary propositions.

sections.ger:
Der Deutlichkeit halber schreiben wir dieses Zeichen nun so:
' p | q | '
W | F | W
W |W | W
F | F | F
F | W | W
Die nach §4.43 auf diese Weise gebauten Satzzeichen nennen wir Satzzeichen der ersten Art.
sections.pmc:
For the sake of perspicuousness we now write this sign in the following way:
' p| q | '
T | F | T
T | T | T
F | F | F
F | T | T
The propositional signs which, according to §4.43, are constructed in this way, we call proposition signs of the first kind.
sections.str: For the sake of clarity we now write this sign as follows:p	qF	F	TT	F	TF	T	FT	T	TThe sentential signs which, according to §4.43, are constructed in this way, we call proposition signs of the first kind.

sections.ger: Die Wahrheitsbedingungen bestimmen den Spielraum der den Tatsachen durch den Satz gelassen wird.
sections.pmc: The truth-conditions of a proposition determine the range that it leaves open to the facts.
sections.str: The truth-conditions of a proposition determine the leeway left to the facts.

sections.ger: Der Satz, das Bild, das Modell, sind, im negativen Sinn, wie ein fester Körper der die Bewegungsfreiheit der anderen beschränkt; im positiven Sinne, wie der von fester Substanz begrenzte Raum, worin ein Körper Platz hat.
sections.pmc: A proposition, a picture, or a model is, in the negative sense, like a solid body that restricts the freedom of movement of others, and, in the positive sense, like a space bounded by solid substance in which there is room for a body.
sections.str: A proposition, a picture, or a model is, in the negative sense, like a solid body which restricts the freedom of movement of another; in a positive sense, like a space bounded by solid substance in which there is room for a body.

sections.ger: WWFW sind also die Wahrheitsbedingungen dieses Satzes. (geändert)
sections.pmc: So TTFT are the truth-conditions of this proposition.
sections.str: So TTFT are the truth-conditions of this proposition.

sections.ger: Die Angabe jeder speziellen Form wäre vollkommen willkürlich.
sections.pmc: It would be completely arbitrary to give any specific form.
sections.str: The specification of any special form would be completely arbitrary.

sections.ger: Wir können also in der Logik nicht sagen: das und das gibt es in der Welt, jenes nicht.
sections.pmc: So we cannot say in logic: 'The world has this in it, and this, but not that.'
sections.str: So  in logic we cannot say: “The world has this in it, and this, but not that.”

sections.ger: Was wir nicht denken können, das können wir nicht denken; wir können also auch nicht sagen, was wir nicht denken können.
sections.pmc: We cannot think what we cannot think. So what we cannot think we cannot say either.
sections.str: We cannot think what we cannot think; so we cannot say what we cannot think.

sections.ger: Die Welt und das Leben sind eins.
sections.pmc: The world and life are one.
sections.str: The world and life are one.

sections.ger: Wenn ich ein Buch schriebe 〟Die Welt, wie ich sie vorfand", so wäre darin auch über meinen Leib zu berichten und zu sagen, welche Glieder meinem Willen unterstehen etc. dies ist nämlich eine Methode das Subjekt zu isolieren, oder vielmehr, zu zeigen daß es in einem wichtigen Sinne kein Subjekt gibt: von ihm allein nämlich, könnte in diesem Buchenicht die Rede sein. —
sections.pmc: If I wrote a book called The World as I found it, I should have to include a report on my body, and should have to say which parts were subordinate to my will, etc., this being a method of isolating the subject, or rather of showing that in an important sense there is no subject; for it alone could not be mentioned in that book.
sections.str: If I were to write a book called The World as I Found It, I would also have to report in it about my body, and say which parts obey my will, etc. This then would be a method of isolating the subject, or rather of showing that in an important sense there is no subject; for it alone could not be mentioned in that book. –

sections.ger:
Es gibt also wirklich einen Sinn in welchem in der Philosophie nicht-psychologisch vom Ich die Rede sein kann.
Das Ich tritt in die Philosophie dadurch ein daß 〟die Welt meine Welt ist".
sections.pmc:
Thus there really is a sense in which philosophy can talk about the self in a non-psychological way.
What brings the self into philosophy is that 'the world is my world'.
sections.str: So there really is a sense in which there can be talk of the I in a non-psychological way in philosophy. What brings the I into philosophy is that “the world is my world”.

sections.ger: Die Wahrheitsmöglichkeiten der Elementarsätze sind die Wahrheitsbedingungen der Sätze.
sections.pmc: Truth-possibilities of elementary propositions are the truth-conditions of propositions.
sections.str: Truth-possibilities of elementary propositions are the truth-conditions ofpropositions.pt

sections.ger: Die allgemeinste Satzform ist: es verhält sich so und so. Diese Form muß in allen Sätzen auf irgend eine Weise enthalten sein.
sections.pmc: The most general propositional form is: This is how things stand. This form must be contained in all propositions in some way or other.
sections.str: The most general propositional form is: such and such is the case. This form must be contained in all propositions in some way or other.

sections.ger: Es ist klar daß dem Komplex der Zeichen 〟F" und 〟W" kein Gegenstand (oder Komplex von Gegenständen) entspricht, so wenig wie den horizontalen und vertikalen Strichen oder den Klammern. 〟Logische Gegenstände" gibt es nicht.
sections.pmc: It is clear that a complex of the signs 'F' and 'T' has no object (or complex of objects) corresponding to it, just as there is none corresponding to the horizontal and vertical lines or to the brackets. There are no 'logical objects'.
sections.str: Clearly, a complex of the signs “F” and “T” has no corresponding object (or complex of objects), just as there is none corresponding to the horizontal and vertical lines or to the brackets. There are no “logical objects”.

sections.ger: Analoges gilt natürlich für alle Zeichen die dasselbe ausdrücken wie die Schemata der W und F".
sections.pmc: Of course the same applies to all signs that express what the schemata of 'T's' and 'F's' express.
sections.str: Naturally, the same applies to all signs that express what the schemas of “T's” and “F 's” express.

sections.ger: Für n Elementarsätze gibt es Ln mögliche Gruppen von Wahrheitsbedingungen.
sections.pmc: For n elementary propositions there are Ln possible groups of truth-conditions.
sections.str: For n elementary propositions there are Ln possible groups of truth-conditions.

sections.ger: Ob aber ein Zeichen der Art F(a,b,c…) analysierbar ist oder nicht, zeigt sich nicht am Zeichen. Sondern wenn es analysierbar ist so zeigt es sich an der bezeichnenden Beziehung. Also daran daß eine analysierende Definition des Zeichens Sinn hat.
sections.pmc: However, whether a sign like F(a, b, c, …) is analyzable or not does not make itself manifest in the sign. Rather, if it is analyzable, that makes itself manifest in the signifying relation, and so in the sign's possessing a definition that anlayzes it and that has sense.
sections.str: However, whether a sign like F (a, b, c, …) is analyzable or not does not show itself in the sign. Rather, if it is analyzable, that shows itself in the signifying relation, and so in the sign's possessing a definition that analyzes it and that has sense.

sections.ger: Wir können jene Frage offen lassen: die Sprache wird sie von selbst entscheiden.
sections.pmc: We can leave that question open: language itself will decide it.
sections.str: We can leave that question open: language itself will decide it.

sections.ger: Das würde nämlich scheinbar voraussetzen daß wir gewisse Möglichkeiten ausschließen und dies kann nicht der Fall sein, da sonst die Logik über die Grenzen der Welt hinaus müßte, wenn sie nämlich diese Grenzen auch von der anderen Seite betrachten könnte.
sections.pmc: For that would appear to presuppose that we were excluding certain possibilities, and this cannot be the case, since it would require that logic should go beyond the limits of the world; for only in that way could it view those limits from the other side as well.
sections.str: For that would appear to presuppose that we have excluded certain possibilities, and this cannot be the case, since this would require that logic should go beyond the limits of the world, as if it could also have a view of those limits from the other side.

sections.ger: Ich bin meine Welt (der Mikrokosmos).
sections.pmc: I am my world, (the microcosm).
sections.str: I am my world (the microcosm).

sections.ger: Das Subjekt gehört nicht zur Welt, sondern es ist eine Grenze der Welt.
sections.pmc: The subject does not belong to the world: rather, it is a limit of the world.
sections.str: The subject is not part of the world, but a limit of the world.

sections.ger: Das philosophische Ich ist nicht der Mensch, nicht der menschliche Körper oder die menschliche Seele von der die Psychologie handelt, sondern das metaphysische Subjekt, die Grenze (nicht ein Teil) der Welt.
sections.pmc: The philosophical self is not the human being, not the human body, or the human soul, with which psychology deals, but rather the metaphysical subject, the limit (not a part) of the world.
sections.str: The philosophical I is not the human being, not the human body, nor the human soul, with which psychology deals, but rather the metaphysical subject, the limit (not a part) of the world.

sections.ger: Die Gruppen von Wahrheitsbedingungen welche zu den Wahrheitsmöglichkeiten einer Anzahl von Elementarsätzen gehören lassen sich in einer Reihe ordnen.
sections.pmc: The groups of truth-conditions that are obtainable from the truth-possibilities of a given number of elementary propositions can be arranged in a series.
sections.str: The groups of truth-conditions that belong to the truth-possibilities of a given number of elementary propositions can be arranged in a series.

sections.ger: Es ist offenbar daß wir bei der Analyse der Sätze auf Elementarsätze kommen müssen die aus Namen in unmittelbarer Verbindung bestehen.
sections.pmc: It is obvious that the analysis of propositions must bring us to elementary propositions which consist of names in immediate combination.
sections.str: Obviously, analysing propositions must lead us to elementary propositions consisting of names in immediate connection.

sections.ger: Es frägt sich hier, wie kommt der Satzverband zustande.
sections.pmc: This raises the question how such combination into propositions comes about.
sections.str: The question here is: how does the propositional connection//combination//nexus// arise?

sections.ger: Eine Hierarchie der Formen der Elementarsätze kann es nicht geben.
sections.pmc: There cannot be a hierarchy of the forms of elementary propositions.
sections.str: There can be no hierarchy of the forms of elementary propositions.

sections.ger: Die Anwendung der Logik entscheidet darüber, welche Elementarsätze es gibt.
sections.pmc: The application of logic decides what elementary propositions there are.
sections.str: The application of logic is what decides what elementary propositions there are.

sections.ger: Was in der Anwendung liegt, kann die Logik nicht vorausnehmen.
sections.pmc: What belongs to its application, logic cannot anticipate.
sections.str: Logic cannot forsee what belongs to its application.

sections.ger: Das ist klar: die Logik darf mit ihrer Anwendung nicht kollidieren.
sections.pmc: It is clear that logic must not clash with its application.
sections.str: Clearly, logic may not clash with its application.

sections.ger: Aber die Logik muß sich mit ihrer Anwendung berühren.
sections.pmc: But logic has to be in contact with its application.
sections.str: But logic and its application must touch each other.

sections.ger: Also dürfen die Logik und ihre Anwendung einander nicht übergreifen.
sections.pmc: Therefore logic and its application must not overlap.
sections.str: Therefore logic and its application may not overlap one another.

sections.ger:
Wo in der Welt ist ein metaphysisches Subjekt zu merken?
Du sagst, es verhält sich hier ganz wie bei Auge und Gesichtsfeld. Aber das Auge siehst Du wirklich nicht. 
Und nichts am Gesichtsfeld läßt darauf schließen daß es von einem Auge gesehen wird.
sections.pmc:
Where in the world is a metaphysical subject to be found?
You will say that this is exactly like the case of the eye and the visual field. But really you do not see the eye.
And nothing in the visual field allows you to infer that it is seen by an eye.
sections.str: Where in the world is a metaphysical subject to be found?You say this is just like the case of the eye and the visual field. But you do not actually see the eye. And nothing in the visual field would enable one to infer that it is seen by an eye.

sections.ger: Das Gesichtsfeld hat nämlich nicht etwa eine solche Form
sections.pmc: For the form of the visual field is surely not like this
sections.str: The form of the visual field is surely not like this:Eye

sections.ger: Unter den möglichen Gruppen von Wahrheitsbedingungen gibt es zwei extreme Fälle.
sections.pmc: Among the possible groups of truth-conditions there are two extreme cases.
sections.str: Among the possible groups of truth-conditions there are two limiting cases.

sections.ger: Ein Zeichen des Elementarsatzes ist es, daß kein Elementarsatz mit ihm in Widerspruch stehen kann.
sections.pmc: It is a sign of a proposition's being elementary that there can be no elementary proposition contradicting it.
sections.str: It is a sign of a proposition's being elementary that no elementary proposition can contradict it.

sections.ger: Nur was wir selbst konstruieren, können wir voraussehen.
sections.pmc: We can forsee only what we ourselves construct.
sections.str: We can foresee only what we ourselves construct.

sections.ger: Elementarsätze bezeichnen wir mit 〟p0", 〟q0", 〟r0", etc. oder mit f0(a), f0(a,b), etc. wobei wir es dahingestellt sein lassen ob a=b ist oder nicht.
sections.pmc: For elementary propositions we use the signs 'p0', 'q0', 'r0', etc. or 'f0(a)', 'f0(a, b)', etc. where it is left open whether or not a = b.
sections.str: For elementary propositions we use the signs “p0”, “q0”, “r0”, etc. or “f0(a)”, “f0(a, b)”, etc. where it is left open whether or not a=b.

sections.ger: Es ist klar wir haben vom Elementarsatz einen Begriff abgesehen von seiner besonderen logischen Form.
sections.pmc: Clearly we have some concept of elementary propositions quite apart from their particular logical forms.
sections.str: Clearly we have the concept of an elementary proposition apart from its particular logical form.

sections.ger: Weiß ich aus rein logischen Gründen, — und so ist es — daß es Elementarsätze geben muß, dann muß es auch jeder andere wissen, der die Sätze in ihrer unanalysierten Form sieht.
sections.pmc: If I know on purely logical grounds - as indeed I do - that there must be elementary propositions, then everyone else who sees propositions in their unanalyzed form must know it too.
sections.str: If I know on purely logical grounds - and I do - that there must be elementary propositions, this must be known by anyone who sees propositions in their unanalysed form.

sections.ger: Wenn ich die Elementarsätze nicht a priori angeben kann, dann muß es zu offenbarem Unsinn führen, sie angeben zu wollen.
sections.pmc: If I cannot say a priori what elementary propositions there are, then the attempt to do so must lead to obvious nonsense.
sections.str: Since I cannot specify a priori what elementary propositions there are, any attempt to do so must lead to obvious nonsense.

sections.ger: Das hängt damit zusammen daß kein Teil unserer Erfahrung auch a priori ist.
sections.pmc: This is connected with the fact that no part of our experience is at the same time a priori.

sections.ger: Im einen Fall ist der Satz für sämtliche Wahrheitsmöglichkeiten der Elementarsätze wahr. Wir sagen die Wahrheitsbedingungen sind tautologisch. Im zweiten Fall ist der Satz für sämtliche Wahrheitsmöglichkeiten falsch; die Wahrheitsbedingungen sind kontradiktorisch.
sections.pmc:
In one of these cases the proposition is true for all the truth-possibilities of the elementary propositions. We say that the truth-conditions are tautological.
In the second case the proposition is all false for all the truth-possibilities: the truth-conditions are contradictory.
sections.str: In one case the proposition is true for all the truth-possibilities of the elementary propositions. We say that the truth-conditions are tautological.
Because a tautology is unconditionally true, it has no truth-conditions; on no condition is a contradiction true.

sections.ger: Im ersten Falle nennen wir den Satz eine Tautologie im zweiten Fall eine Kontradiktion.
sections.pmc: In the first case we call the proposition a tautology; in the second, a contradiction.
sections.str: In the first case we call the proposition a tautology; in the second, a contradiction.

sections.ger: Analytische Sätze sind Tautologien.
sections.pmc: Analytical propositions are tautologies.
sections.str: Analytic propositions are tautologies.

sections.ger: Auch wenn die Welt unendlich komplex wäre, so daß jede Tatsache aus unendlich vielen Sachverhalten bestünde und jeder Sachverhalt aus unendlich vielen Gegenständen zusammengesetzt wäre; auch dann müßte es Gegenstände und Sachverhalte geben.
sections.pmc: Even if the world were infinitely complex, so that every fact consisted of infinitely many states of affairs and every state of affairs were composed of infinitely many objects, there would still have to be objects and states of affairs.
sections.str: Even if the world were infinitely complex, so that every fact consisted of infinitely many elementary facts and every elementary fact were composed of infinitely many objects, there would still have to be objects and elementary facts.

sections.ger: Die empirische Realität ist begrenzt durch die Gesamtheit der Gegenstände. Die Grenze zeigt sich wieder in der Gesamtheit der Elementarsätze. Die Hierarchien sind und müssen unabhängig von der Realität sein.
sections.pmc:
Empirical reality is limited by the totality of objects.
The limit also makes itself manifest in the totality of objects.
Hierarchies are and must be independent of reality.
sections.str: Empirical reality is limited by the totality of objects. The limit also shows itself in the totality of objects. Hierarchies are and must be independent of reality.

sections.ger:
Alles was wir sehen, könnte auch anders sein.
Alles was wir überhaupt beschreiben können, könnte auch anders sein.
sections.pmc:
Whatever we see could be other than it is.
Whatever we can describe at all could be other than it is.
sections.str: All we see could also be otherwise.All we can describe at all could also be otherwise.

sections.ger: Tautologien sind sinnlos. (Ich weiß z.B. nichts über das Wetter wenn ich weiß daß es regnet oder nicht regnet.)
sections.pmc: Tautologies lack sense. (For example, I know nothing about the weather when I know that it is either raining or not raining.)
sections.str: Tautologies lack sense. (For example, I know nothing about the weather when I know that it is either raining or not raining.)

sections.ger: Der Satz zeigt was er sagt, die Tautologie und Kontradiktion, daß sie nichts sagen.
sections.pmc: Propositions show what they say: tautologies and contradictions show that they say nothing.
sections.str: A proposition shows what it says: a tautology and a contradiction show that they say nothing.

sections.ger: Alle Sätze unserer Umgangssprache sind tatsächlich, so wie sie sind, logisch vollkommen geordnet. — Jenes Einfachste, was wir hier angeben sollen, ist nicht ein Gleichnis der Wahrheit, sondern die volle Wahrheit selbst. (Unsere Probleme sind nicht abstrakt, sondern vielleicht die konkretesten die es gibt.)
sections.pmc:
In fact, all the propositions of our everyday language, just as they stand, are in perfect logical order. - That utterly simple thing, which we have to formulate here, is not an image of the truth, but the truth itself in its entirety.
(Our problems are not abstract, but perhaps the most concrete that there are.)
sections.str: All the propositions of our ordinary language are actually, just as they are, in perfect logical order. - That utterly simple thing, that we have to formulate here, is not a likeness of the truth, but the complete truth itself. (Our problems are not abstract, but on the contrary, as concrete as they can be.)

sections.ger: Es gibt keine Ordnung der Dinge a priori.
sections.pmc: There is no a priori order of things.
sections.str: There is no order of things a priori.

sections.ger: Tautologie und Kontradiktion sind sinnlos.
sections.pmc: Tautologies and contradictions lack sense.
sections.str: Tautologies and contradictions lack sense.

sections.ger: (Wie der Punkt von dem zwei Pfeile in entgegengesetzter Richtung auseinander gehen)
sections.pmc: (Like a point from which two arrows go out in opposite directions to one another.)
sections.str: (Like a point with two arrows going out in opposite directions.)

sections.ger: Tautologie und Kontradiktion sind (sinnlos) nicht unsinnig. Sie gehören zum Symbolismus und zwar ähnlich wie die 0 in die Arithmetik.
sections.pmc: Tautologies and contradictions are not nonsensical (but lack sense). They are part of the symbolism, just as '0' is in arithmetic.
sections.str: Tautologies and contradictions are not nonsense (but lack sense). They belong to the symbolism, just like “0” in arithmetic.

sections.ger: Tautologie und Kontradiktion sind nicht Bilder der Wirklichkeit. Sie stellen keine mögliche Sachlage dar. Denn jene läßt jedemögliche Sachlage zu, diese keine.
sections.pmc: Tautologies and contradictions are not pictures of reality. They do not represent any possible situations. For the former admit all possible situations, and the latter none.
sections.str: Tautologies and contradictions are not pictures of reality. They represent no possible situations. For tautologies admit all possible situations, and contradictions admit none.

sections.ger: In der Tautologie heben die Bedingungen der Übereinstimmung mit der Welt — die darstellenden Beziehungen — einander auf, so daß sie in keiner darstellenden Beziehung zur Wirklichkeit steht.
sections.pmc: In a tautology the conditions of agreement with the world - the representational relations - cancel one another, so that it does not stand in any representational relation to reality.
sections.str: In a tautology the conditions of agreement with the world - the representing relations - cancel one another, so that it does not stand in any  representing relation to reality.

sections.ger: In der Tautologie bildet der Elementarsatz selbstverständlich noch immer ab, aber er ist mit der Wirklichkeit so lose verbunden daß diese unbeschränkte Freiheit hat. Die Kontradiktion setzt solche Schranken, daß keine Wirklichkeit in ihnen existieren kann.
sections.pmc: Of course in a tautology an elementary proposition still depicts, but it is so loosely connected with reality that it leaves it unbounded freedom. The bounds set by a contradiction are such that no reality can exist within them.
sections.str: Of course in a tautology an elementary proposition still depicts, but it is so loosely connected with reality as to leave it unlimited freedom. The bounds set by a contradiction are such that no reality can exist within them.

sections.ger: Die Tautologie läßt der Wirklichkeit den ganzen — unendlichen — logischen Raum frei; die Kontradiktion erfüllt den ganzen logischen Raum und läßt der Wirklichkeit keinen Punkt. Keine von beiden kann daher die Wirklichkeit irgendwie bestimmen.
sections.pmc: A tautology leaves open to reality the whole - the infinite whole - of logical space: a contradiction fills the whole of logical space leaving no point of it for reality. Thus neither of them can determine reality in any way.
sections.str: A tautology leaves the whole infinite logical space open to reality; a contradiction fills the whole of logical space, leaving no point to reality. Thus neither of them can determine reality in any way.

sections.ger: Die Wahrheit der Tautologie ist gewiß, des Satzes möglich, der Kontradiktion unmöglich.
sections.pmc: A tautology's truth is certain, a proposition's possible, a contradiction's impossible.
sections.str: The truth of tautology is certain, of propositions possible, of contradiction impossible.

sections.ger: Das logische Produkt einer Tautologie und eines Satzes sagt dasselbe wie der Satz. Also ist jenes Produkt identisch mit dem Satz. Denn man kann das Wesentliche des Zeichens nicht ändern ohne seinen Sinn zu ändern.
sections.pmc: The logical product of a tautology and a proposition says the same thing as the proposition. This product, therefore, is identical with the proposition. For it is impossible to alter what is essential to a sign without altering its sense.
sections.str: The logical product of a tautology and a proposition says the same thing as the proposition. This product, therefore, is identical with the proposition. For the essence of a sign cannot be altered without altering its sense.

sections.ger:
Einer bestimmten logischen Verbindung von Zeichen entspricht eine bestimmte logische Verbindung ihrer Bedeutungen; jede beliebige Verbindung entspricht nur den unverbundenen Zeichen.
Das heißt, Sätze die für jede Sachlage wahr sind können überhaupt keine Zeichenverbindungen sein, denn sonst könnten ihnen nur bestimmte Verbindungen von Gegenständen entsprechen.
(Und keiner logischen Verbindung entspricht keine Verbindung der Gegenstände.)
sections.pmc:
What corresponds to a determinate logical combination of signs is a determinate logical combination of their meanings. It is only to the uncombined signs that absolutely any combination corresponds.
In other words, propositions that are true for every situation cannot be combinations of signs at all, since, if they were, only determinate combinations of objects could correspond to them.
(And what is not a logical combination has no combination of objects corresponding to it.)
sections.str: A definite logical combination of signs corresponds to a definite logical combination of their meanings. It is only to the uncombined signs that absolutely any combination corresponds. That is, propositions that are true for every situation cannot be combinations of signs at all, for otherwise, only definite combinations of objects would correspond to them. (And what isn’t a logical combination has no combination of objects corresponding to it.)

sections.ger: Die Tautologie ist der Grenzfall der Zeichenverbindung nämlich ihre Auflösung.
sections.pmc: Tautology is the limiting case, indeed the disintegration, of the combination of signs.
sections.str: Tautology is a limiting case of the combination of signs, namely their disintegration.

sections.ger: Gewiß, möglich, unmöglich: hier haben wir das Anzeichen jener Gradation, die wir in der Wahrscheinlichkeitslehre brauchen.
sections.pmc: Certain, possible, impossible: here we have the first indication of the scale that we need in the theory of probability.
sections.str: Certain, possible, impossible: here we have an indication of the scale needed in probability theory.
